author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Anyone who has experience with something like Plug in Alliance Paul Frindle’s DSM will know that it’s excellent at high mid and high frequency manipulation but at 16 bands has almost no low end resolution

Soothe has (according to a post from the developer) 4096 bins in Normal Resolution Mode. This accounts for it’s (to me) generally very blurry sound, but that can be very useful in certain contexts and if used with care in the higher octaves can be a very worthwhile tradeoff

K, won’t be around for follow up questions today but tag me and I’ll reply tomorrow

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I am loving the De-emphasis section on Tupe. It lets you squeeze so much saturation out of a signal without driving things too hard. 

First, you drive your signal to the point where the loudest part starts to break up, then you use the de-emphasis to subtract that frequency from the saturation circuit and then you push the gain up even harder until you're on the edge of breakup again. Wash, rinse, repeat. 

What you end up with is a signal that's evenly saturated across the entire frequency range instead of only having the loudest parts treated, because they're all hitting the saturation at roughly the same level. This thing is amazing. It's the sound that I've been searching for for soooo long.

author: BatMeckley

Sunday reminder: don’t apply global eq on a track to fix one thing on the track.

I’ve been kicking around this mix and there was a resonance in some of the vocal bits, so I had an eq or 2 on the track to even them out. Maybe some multiband. author: Colin Althaus
content:
Now if you put this HPF on only the Side channel, at 100Hz what was originally +S becomes -S (180 degrees out of phase). So any 100Hz on the left now shifts to the right, and vice versa.

So say you have a rack tom with a fundamental at 100Hz panned hard left. Apply this filter to the S channel and its 100Hz fundamental will sound like it’s coming out of the right side. But the top end of the tom will still sound like it’s coming from the left.

Very extreme example, but seen this happen IRL more than once. Easiest to hear this on headphones if you’d like to experiment.

I’ve found the easiest way to avoid this is to use very gentle M-S slopes (gentle = less phase shift), shelves and bells, and especially avoid any steep HPF or LPF (18 dB/oct or greater).

author: Matt Huber
content:
Ah yes. The monthly tailspin, I know it well 😂

One thing that I have found to be very helpful to reduce masking / increase clarity  is to simply start by going track to track and listening for / EQing out non musical resonances and non-musical buildups. 

I am definitely NOT suggesting the aggressive hyper notching you see in a lot of YouTube tutorials, but a general track to track cleanup of obvious issues. Don’t over think it, only attack the obvious things 

Hypothetical Examples:
- weird 1.5k resonant ring in the hats and overheads…notch that thing down a bit. You’d be surprised how much space that takes up in a dense mix. 
- high lead guitar part with extraneous rumble at 200hz…not contributing to the musicality of the part…byeeee
- piano building up at 300hz in the choruses when everything is competing for midrange - automate EQ in chorus to create space 


Etc etc etc. 

Small moves like that have made some of the biggest differences for me. Definitely not the fanciest tip, but simple EQ moves have been the biggest contributor to midrange clarity for me.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Maybe I can try and distill down some suggestions from the conversation for avoiding the pit of despair while referencing:

1) Don't get stuck going back and forth constantly between your mix and your reference - you can get trapped in a loop

2) Think critically about what elements are in the reference track versus what you are working with - is there enough overlap in production and arrangement that makes this a good reference?

3) Focus on the broad strokes - I've seen it described on the server before as "where the edges are" - how wide is the mix, where's the top end sitting, where's the low end sitting, and what are the elements dominating those frequency spectrums

4) Careful not to shy away from what the track wants to be to make it conform to the bell curve

I'm probably missing a lot of things but here's a start?

author: BatMeckley
content: Thank you for the kind words. Also, I’ll occasionally put on something I love fairly late in the mixing process just to make sure I’m not WAY off. But whenever I try to match things I feel like it makes my mix more bland. I actually WANT my mix to have the bass too loud, or too much snare or whatever. A buddy of mine just listened to a rough of a rock song im doing with one of my favorite bands and he’s like “holy shit this song should just be called ‘Toms and Heavy Guitars’” and it felt like mission accomplished. I’m so bored by status quo, I want things to pop out at me, I want elements to be FEATURED. Mixing to me is less about “does this hi hat have enough 5k” and more “what are the 3 most important things at any one time in the song and can I hear/feel them”. There’s a place for knowing how to eq or saturate properly but to me that’s like wayyy behind knowing what’s supposed to be the featured part of the track. (And that’s going to probably different than whatever track I’m referencing)

author: cian riordan
content: This is a fun trick we discovered in the early days of Saturn. Eric came from tape and he was always cranking the high end on the record side going to tape to account for noise on mix down (easier to tame low end than it is to boost when you're mixing off of tape)... but there was a cool high end sheen that you'd get. So with Saturn, you just separate a high frequency band above what is really audible and just crank the gain on the warm tape setting. Obviously you can adjust to taste, but it's a great way to add a little air & excitement to some dull recordings.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Feel like JJ really covered a lot of ground. What I can add from my own experience is 

1) having people better than you listen to your mix. I remember a music supervisor off handedly mentioning a film mixer having to take out a lot of 1k in my mix and I’ve been sensitive about building up frequencies there ever since.

2) remember that mixing is as much about decision making as it is about pure sonics. I know for a fact that I’ve won mixing gigs because someone else’s mix in the shootout might’ve had better sonics, but mine FELT better. Make decisions on what element is getting priority and in what frequency. Don’t get so caught up in minimizing imperfections that you forget to maximize the magic bits.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I don’t know how other people do it, but for me the crux of it is that, if both are occupying the sub range, there WILL BE phase cancellation when they are playing the same note. Some notes will be louder and other softer as a result. 

How you want to solve that is up to you. 

You could: 
1. High pass one and let the other rule the low end. Experiment with linear phase vs normal. 

2. Go note by note and ensure that they are phase aligned and working together. This is tedious but the results are GREAT. This is what I do 99% of the time.

author: bobby k
content: i learned something new about Soothe yesterday that I found valuable - the "soft" vs "hard" mode doesn't affect ratio so much as it affects how the threshold behaves. Soft has what I understand to be a "smart" floating threshold that kind of rides the signal, versus hard is closer to a fixed threshold (and I believe depth then affects the ratio and threshold in it's own way). So, if you were trying to zone in on a frequency that only occasionally rears it's head, hard mode with a lower depth will be generally more accurate and not affect the other parts of the audio nearly as much. I don't like using Soothe on sibilance, but I actually found it quite effective after learning this by setting it to hard mode with a very broad "sharpness".

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I picked up Jon and @oaklandmatt ‘s tip and started doing throws pretty exclusively directly on tracks. 

When the lead vocal is most of the way there (maybe there’ll be subtle adjustments to the LV processing, but it’s more or less up to EU regulations), I do a *commit up to this insert* (which keeps it mono, rather than a right click commit on the track title) on the whole vocal. 

I mute the entire resulting clip, then just unmute the bits I need for a given throw. I’ll duplicate this track (without inserts), maybe end up with 4 of them with different FX chains. It’s no biggie just for a H-Delay and a vintageverb/metaflanger/ whatever.

Like they mentioned on the podcast, this method encourages more experimentation for me, and also circumvents niggly things like trying to get a word to echo on the downbeat if it was sung on an offbeat - you just move the clip forward or backward in time. And if an Ess is too apparent, you can clip gain it down in the source etc.

Plus once you have your verb throw set, when you in turn commit that throw, whatever it is about seeing the audio just suggests further details like having it cut abruptly on a beat, or reverse it, or fade it in, or EQ it etc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is tangentially related, but I think Gullfoss can be a helpful guide-rail for new/intermediate mixers, but it requires commitment to the premise to be effective. I'll explain:

When used on the Master Buss, Gullfoss can provide a positive improvement in mixes. The trouble comes if you have a habit of solo'ing your tracks or groups when you mix. When you solo, Gullfoss will adjust it's curve to optimize for the solo'ed sound. This can lead mixers to make changes to the solo'ed elements that are even *less* effectual than if they'd been solo'ing on a non-Gullfoss buss. It can lead inexperienced mixers to chase their tail even more if they aren't careful.

So I'll summarize it like this: To gain benefit from Gullfoss you have to commit to mixing without solo'ing (generally a good practice), otherwise it will continually re-adjust itself and exacerbate the tail-chasing that comes from mixing and making moves while solo'ed.

author: Adam Thein
content:
If there's some breath there, if you have RX Advanced there's a module called "Deconstruct" that Ruairi mentioned to me once when I had the opposite problem where there was a ton of air being pushed and not a lot of resonance.  It separates between tonal and noisy parts of the signal and gives you volume slider.  This will only help you if there's some breathiness to bring up that isn't buried at the level of the noise floor.

If you don't want to do a whisper track + vocalign you can also play around with a Vocoder with the carrier being noise or a sample of breath and blend that in parallel.

I think new whisper track plus vocalign will get you there the fastest and most convincing.

author: cian riordan
content: I find that super low volume listening helps with this. Take a 5 min break, turn your shit all the way down, and have a listen. If you can make out the vocals amongst the arrangement, you’re in a good place. If not? First angle of attack is volume. If it’s still sounding swamped, then start picking out offending parts of the arrangement with eq cuts — almost anywhere in the midrange.

author: cian riordan
content: With bass, I'm usually compressing the bass and getting the DI pumping how I like, then bringing the level up in to the -4 to -6 dbFS or so. Then I'll make a mono, post fader send to a mono aux with sansamp. I'll send a healthy level then start by adding a little bit of drive, then playing with the buzz, punch, and crunch to fold in the distortion -- but thinking of it like an EQ. Using it to fill in the harmonic gaps that aren't cutting through when the drums and guitars are going. Very rarely touching the high/low eq on the right.

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, got my car back from the shop today and they accidentally fucked up the stereo so that the amp that runs the low end and subs (and back speaker) wasn’t working, so I had to listen to music without basically anything under let’s say 300, and it got me thinking about our conversations about mixing.

I think a lot of the new (and even some of the experienced mixers here) would find out some neat stuff about mixes they like if they brought one into their daw, selected a hyper aggressive low pass (brick wall?) and then scooted it down to say 300 hz. What’s left in the song do you hear? Then down to 200. Down to 100. Down to 26. What exactly is in the low end information of the mixes you enjoy? I’d then flip it to a high pass and go the other way. How much of the bass is above 1k? The kick? I think it would be eye opening for some. 
Shawn Everett once showed me this great mix trick where he low pass something, say a vocal, and slides it all the way down until he can’t hear anything important anymore, and then just switches it from a low pass to a hi pass. (And vice versa). Pretty useful trick to make some space in your mixes.

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, old school I know, but you can chase de essers around for 6 hours or you can just go through with an eq and print the ess sounds in the track. Take down a high shelf, or a wide q dip, find what works on that particular chain, and it should be fairly consistent across most of the esses. Just knock ‘em down right from the jump. Will prob take an hour or so but then your in a much better place for further automated processing down the road.I

author: BatMeckley
content:
I have questions.
Why are you doing multiple proq3 next to each other? (As someone who accidentally found themself doing the same thing). I understand maybe, pre compressor/post compressor… but a bunch in a row?

Also, eq is rarely a victimless crime. Each point you add is going to add a resonance or a phase shift or what not. I try to get away with doing the least amount possible, while also trying to not be afraid of “doing what it takes”. What I usually find is I’ll go overboard initially, and then start bypassing things to make sure that my changes were actually making my things better overall, and that I didn’t lose the forrest for the trees, hurting the big pictures chasing after something insignificant

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Here’s the one other thing about Serban that I think is obvious, but seemingly overlooked a lot

There’s a trade off between dynamic control/having things locked in place, and allowing things to be wilder. Mixes where things are locked in place sound more similar everywhere, they are in a sense robust. Mixes with braver dynamic or EQ choices can be much more exciting under ideal conditions, but do less well at the edges of the bell curve (mono overhead speaker at the supermarket for example)

Serban’s mixes are very locked in place, dynamically and from a frequency point of view and so he has great translation. I rarely find it to get in the way of the song, but some of my mixer friends will go to the mat about how it could have been so much more …. And maybe they’re right

But if you win the race, and the song comes through then how much more do you need to win it by? His mixes do the job of getting pop songs into my ears, and give A&R confidence and comfort, a lot to like …

author: BatMeckley
content: Make a new duplicate snare track. Gate the hell out of it. Also band pass it to roughly the frequency that’s bumming you out. Use that as your side chain key. You can bring the gain up or down to affect the threshold. On soothe use the high and low pass filter to further narrow down the offending frequency, and then use a bell eq and raise or lower it at 10k to affect the threshold. (That’s essentially soothes threshold setting). You got this.

author: kylem
content: I’ve used this trick to rebuild shitty top end in a vocal. Lofi as first plugin, pull down sample rate 1 click, adjust aliasing, then put top back using a pultec (or something similar). Also can do something similar across a whole mix / sub groups using standard clips built in filter. Can help get a more focused top. Also can completely ruin things! Fun to play with

author: chrissorem
content: I have a real ATR as well as the plugin and I treat them both the same. It’s a color with different eq curves. Some times I like and sometimes I don’t. I’ve had it make a mix really work and I’ve had the opposite too.  I’m thinking out loud here but I’d say the downside of mixing in the box is the amount we over think about the things. It’s easy to get into a phase or template and a mindset of what you should or should not do. I think I can be good to  forget some of these “rules”  and go back to listening. sometimes it’s good to work into something and it may not be the best right when you Insert it and you might have to change the bass relationship ect…  but at the end you might find yourself in a more interesting place.

author: Matt Huber
content:
Allllllll the time. I feel like sometimes I can get to the finish line with it, other times, it makes it utterly impossible to get it beyond 85% done. 

I find that most folks slap on a multiband comp because they like the tonal shape of it. 

So, one thing that I find very helpful in situations like this is to think about these mix busses as contributing 2 different things - dynamics and tonality, and recreate those things in a less convoluted way. 

Practical example (from a mix last week): 

Capture the EQ shape of the entire chain using Ozone EQ match, then bring things up to a similar level using a single limiter. 

In the case of the song I was mixing, I instantly had the vibe / shape of the producer mix buss without the limitations of mixing into layers of highly interactive processing.

author: peterlabberton
content: I posted about this years ago, but when tracking, sometimes I’ll mult the kick, send to my Moog Grandmother, roll the filter waaaayy down and crank the resonance up, and then you can really tune where the fundamental is. And you can get really wild exaggerated low end. Phase reverse and see which way hits harder, then tuck it in. I’ve never tried it on snare but I assume it’d work—and I’ve adapted this in the box too with any ol’ eq and some saturation. Fun!

author: bobby k
content: a theme of 2025 i've been exploring is boosting on EQ more. In the past my thought process has been - this element buried in a dense mix is really poking out at xyz frequency, so i'm going to reduce that frequency to make it sound more "balanced". (take for example something like a screeching ambient guitar solo or vocal riff sitting in the background during ~big chorus 3~). Lately i've been challenging myself to actually push UP the frequencies that really make up the certain track's identity, then focusing on it's volume in the mix instead. so far this has felt like things in an arrangement each have a more tangible attitude, instead of where I was at in the past where everything was silky smooth and balanced, thus becoming a soft-midrange-soup. The instinct is as simple as something like make believes MBSI strip, with the midrange EQ knob that can boost or cut, where I would usually use it to cut a dense part of that element, i'll now *boost* it and just turn the track down. Been sounding so much cooler.

author: chrissorem
content: I just posted something over in #📸show-your-setup talking about many different ways of recording a bass drum. I usually have between two and four, microphones for kick.  one is generally for low frequency if not two for low frequency, and the others are capturing different versions of the attack of the kick, I don’t think too much about it. I just put the faders  up and start experimenting to see what I think is best for the song. I tend to think  a lot more about the physical drum and the treatment of the drum and beater  pedal more than I do about how I’m going to treat the relationship between the mics.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As Justin and Zack said, there's no wrong answer here. It's achievable both ways.

But since you're having trouble getting your verbs to pop out in the way you want, here are a few things that will get you there. Usually a combination of these things:

**1.** Turn up the verb - Simple, I know.
**2.** Make space for the verb - Mute or EQ competing elements.
**3.** Increase your pre-delay time to the range of 60ms - 150 ms. This "disconnects" your verb from the source and makes it stand out more. And this sometimes means you can turn it down and still have the clarity. 
**4.** Use an echo instead of a verb - This sometimes does the thing and takes up less space.
**5.** Use a slap echo instead of a verb - One and done. Gives you that room-y feel without taking up a lot of space.
**6.** EQ muddy/thick/harsh frequencies out of your verb, so that you can turn it up louder without overwhelming the mix.
**7.** Gently apply an effect (distortion, phaser, etc) that will make it contrast and catch the ear easier.

author: chrissorem
content:
It seems like you might be spending to much time in the micro nuances of mixing. (Easy to do that)  try a new approach. Make quick moves and jump to something else, if the kick is too….. it will remind you everytime you listen. Try  to step back and listen to your mixes like a ME. Is there too much or not enough of a certain frequency range?  Then dive back into the micro move adjust and move on. This helps  you stay in the flow and to not get lost  in the weeds.  In my experience the music tells you most of what you need to know. Tempo has a huge effect on how the low end can work. Density often determines how midrange and upper mid/ high freq should work.  The elements in the mix should be serving particular roles and that informs where things should sit and ultimately equal how it makes you feel. I don’t think very much when I mix but I react to what’s in front of me . 
The more you do this the more this will lock in. Another thing that comes to mind, is sometimes if I’m feeling like something isn’t right I’ll do a save as or In your example I’ll mute the kick and duplicate it and start from scratch and see if I can beat it. Sometimes order of operations can lead you down certain paths and as other elements enter the original moves might not being working

author: cian riordan
content:
So for all the mixing nerds here, thought you mind find this interesting. For the past 6 months or so I've embraced the idea of having an analog mix buss. I've always strayed away from it in lieu of keeping things fluid for easy recalls. However, since I've been doing 100% of my mixing in this studio and this gear probably isn't goin anywhere, I've been more comfortable leaning on a hardware chain with (what I think are) great results. 

First, I'm going into an old UTA Unfairchild. This was the first model that came out with the 6BC8 tubes instead of the current 6386 tubes. I always preferred the older model and was lucky to snatch one when Barefoot kicked the bucket. I'm not actually doing any compression, I've just got gain at unity and signal passing through. The second stage is a pair of UTA MPEQ-1's. I *thought* that I was doing a high shelf boost starting at 8.3k going into a LPF @ 22k. 

I've really, really been enjoying the sound of this. I notice a little midrange clarity from the unfairchild and I find the additive high end on the buss is much more musical than boosting individual elements.

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve moved away from housekeeping passes like that. I called it “eating my vegetables”, where I’d assist myself - tuning, de-clicking etc ideally with a gap before sitting down to mix proper. 

Now, unless it’s a real train wreck I usually prefer to jump straight into the mix and see what comes out in the wash. 

I sometimes found myself being a hammer and everything looking like a nail, maybe tuning too tightly and needing to relax it once the mix had been built up. Or like how mastering can reveal issues that weren’t spotted in the mix, when the vocal chain and mixbus high shelf are in, clicks would be revealed that I wouldn’t have heard before, so I l’d wind up having to do another pass anyway.

Maybe most importantly though, by the time I got to mixing I could wind up already too familiar with the song and it’s nice to come at it fresh like clean socks.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I think this is an area where Soothe excels for me. 

My general method: 

1. LISTEN and identify before opening Soothe. Make a mental note of where the problem lies in the frequency spectrum. Get very specific. 

2. Open up soothe and use the filters to target that narrow area. Play around with the attack & sharpness and dial in the depth until the problem starts diminishing. 

3. Often, that general area will feel a tad bit dull. If so, boost the area with a wide bell to bring back all the good stuff now that the weird spiky resonances are dealt with.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW: I never use auto align and have only used time adjuster to move room mics a little further away for effect. If things aren’t sounding locked with a simple polarity flip, I’ll quickly try and tinker with a HPF on key drum elements (kick, snare, etc). After that, I’ll resort to mountain moving EQ or samples. If someone didn’t have the skills and/or thought to record their drum mics in phase, then it’s very likely they’re not worth going through brain surgery to salvage them. Get them doing the fundamentals and move on with the mix.

author: kylem
content: I set a timer. If I’m working on a bunch of different songs that are all on pressing deadlines, 45 minutes. If it’s a same day turnaround it gets a bit more difficult to do this. I think most important thing is to just stay zoomed out as much as possible and not get in the weeds on any one thing. author: JustinLeu
content:
I am using a lot of un-shared verb sends to make stem printing quick/clean.

I will use EQ on verbs quite a bit, but one thing I really like is to put soothe before the verb and focus it on all the resonant harsh stuff. (Mostly doing this for vocals)

Also throwing a transient designer before the verb can make them less obvious.

Or a slow attack gate for vocals 25+ms keyed to 500-ish (avoids esses and breaths nicely)

author: BatMeckley
content:
As someone who made a living for a while making absurdly loud mixes, I would look at trying to take the low end out of absolutely everything that doesn’t need to be there. Hi passing or shelving almost everything except the kick, and one (or two at most) bass element. And/or sidechain that low end to the primary low end instrument.

Counter intuitively, getting rid of all the bass out of your tracks can actually make your master feel more bass heavy.

It’s wild how much low end garbage is recorded by modern gear, and it just builds up over the entire session. I’d go with the Shawn Everett trick of putting a low pass filter on a track, slide it all the way down until you don’t hear anything useful, and then flip it to a high pass filter.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
first off, if it sounds good, do it. i know that starts to sound like an annoying cliche, but it's ALWAYS good to re-remind yourself. there are no rules with this shit and the more your learn about the technical side the LESS you should rely on it. because your ears are getting better and thus you should be trusting them more.

the phase shift from a bell curve is much more subtle compared to HP and LP filtering, so it tends to add back in much better when used in parallel. also there are plenty situations where you might actually *like* the phase shift, where you're boosting something like upper mid range and you get just a teeny bit of blur in the low mids. there are good articles online that graph it, but i'd say just be mindful of phase by flipping the parallel channel and seeing what it does. and trust ya ears and just do what sounds good to you!

content: By this logic, you could argue that any tool in a mixers toolbox is a band aid to a problem created in recording. Compression a bandaid for something recorded too dynamically. HPF a bandaid for something that was incorrectly recorded with too much low end. A Pultec high boost a bandaid for something too dark. Sometimes you get a vocal that has a pokey resonance that happens at 3k and if you try cutting with EQ, it kills the aggressiveness… but if you do it dynamically, it only snags it when the frequency poked 15 dB above where it should.

content:
Nope.  Bad arrangement.
This is why I harp on bedroom guitarists vs recording vs touring guitarist. If you’re by yourself a big meaty full frequency tone is satisfying. If you’re tracking guitars youre high passing so much more than you’d initially think to make room for bass and kick. If you’re in your bedroom, a tube screamer kinda blows. More often than not is tracked through something like a pignose. Way band limited.

author: JakeTB
content:
All of @popaganda. 's info is great here. To go one step further on the controls for a beginner- If you are using eq, that implies that you have already diagnosed a problem, which you'll be solving with eq. When you think of that problem, what words do you use? (i.e., this is way too dark, this needs a little more highs, that frequency hurts, etc.). 
If you find yourself talking about broader things like "highs" or "lows", that probably indicates a wide Q is appropriate. If you find yourself talking about "that ringing" or "the fundamental", that probably indicates a narrow Q is appropriate. 

Frequency, Bandwidth (Q), and Gain are all balance elements, as eq is a tool for balancing frequencies with one another. I'd avoid using the key of the song or phase when considering eq choices as a beginner. Just train and trust your ears.

A tool that can be helpful in training your ears for EQ usage is "Blindfold EQ" by Audiothing (https://www.audiothing.net/effects/blindfold-eq/), which is a free EQ plugin with no numbers or indicators for the controls.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I am presently really fascinated by the relationship between frequency and perceived height in a mix. I feel like it all comes down to arrangement. 'Descriptive language' = 'frequency' like @NoahNeedleman mentioned feels of limited use depending on whether you are a starter or finisher of the record perhaps. It's all relative and everything effects everything. I've started to imagine my arrangements / mixes in a sort of dynamic spherical (ish) three dimensional anti-gravity space where I can push and pull the objects of my arrangement / mix forward and back or up and down. I am still exploring this model / searching for better language. My producer brain asks is all the information already there. My mixer brain asks what unnecessary information came along with the objects of my mix. You can pull up or out and forward on an object with a shelf or bell shaped boost or you can push back and away or remove altogether the unnecessary information (HPF or low shelf) suspending what remains above. I have been exploring the latter and I think it has benefited my mixes with the perception of height and informing high frequency mix decisions.

author: thecoleyoung
content:
Lots of great thoughts and technical experience already shared from Ruairi here, but want to tell a funny story on this “logic sounds smeary” thought. 

I had a production that I made in logic in 2020, and was really happy with it. We had a decent budget for mixing, so off it goes and we get a wonderful mix back. 

I was pretty new to all this at the time, and after hearing that great mix next to my shitty rough mix, I immediately thought logic had to be part of the problem cause I had heard talks of “smeary”, so I jumped ship to pro tools and have been there for the last four years. 

Come to find out a few months ago, the mixer had mixed that song IN LOGIC, and was just working from my session hahaha. 

It’s also the most streamed (and to me favorite sounding) song on that album, and was the only one mixed in Logic. 

Not trying to muddy the waters for you here, but that experience was really helpful and freeing for me! Pro tools is obviously great, and if you have the itch it’s likely worth exploring. But I haven’t found any truth to there being inherit sonic benefits from working in Pro Tools vs. Logic.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This reminds me of an important point: Most sounds in the mix don't actually need to be stereo. And a snare drum is probably not one of them. You can create a lot of space in your mix by reducing all but a few key elements to mono. Keyboards and synths are a huge offender here.

A lot of mixers/producers assume that the instruments need to be stereo, when in fact it's the *mix* that should be stereo. And the most "stereo" mix is often created by panning mono instruments in the stereo field. Getting those pan balances right is going to remove a lot of conflict between instruments sharing similar frequency ranges.

You can still have stereo reverbs and echoes, but they can often be far more narrow than the default setting of 100% width. So don't overlook narrowing your stereo elements too.

It's amazing how much you can do with nothing but faders, pan knobs, and EQ.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I find myself reaching for super gentle low pass filters in this situation (3db/octave). 

The most important part for me is to avoid getting too caught up in comparing the slightly darker mix with the brighter one because of the whole “brighter / louder always sounds more exciting” dynamic.

I’ll step away, let my ears forget the “brighter” one, and then evaluate the new version on its own merits. Does it still feel like it needs that extension or does the new level of brightness serve the song well? Does it still feel crispy or has that sense gone away?

author: BatMeckley
content:
This goes counter to a lot of the conventional wisdom here, but I’ve always found listening somewhere else, while doing something else, incredibly helpful. When mixing, I try to take  some time to take in music the way that most people do, which isn’t hunched in front of my expensive monitors in my treated room hyper analyzing the 4k. 

Yesterday I was asking my buddy Spencer who lives in Georgia about a drum edit, and I could hear him listening to the song through the phone and realized the vocals were too hot. 

Little things like that can help me recenter on what’s important.

author: Rob Domos
content: I do something similar fairly often. If the musicality of the notes of an element aren’t coming through or things feel foggy rather than solid, often it’s because harmonics are competing with the fundamental for what pitch we perceive it as. It’s astonishing how often “this sound sucks” is really just the first harmonic being louder than the fundamental and is fixed with a simple EQ bell or two

author: chrissorem

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I am pretty much always happy with: 

1. The old generic waves de-esser 
2. A bit of clip gain beforehand
3. Audiosuite EQ or RX as needed
4. A bit of fader riding after

author: cian riordan
content: I am a guy that HPF's most tracks in my mixes, AMA.

author: peterlabberton
content: 👋🏻 another fan of high passing most everything besides bass and kick—and often even those elements to zero in on the fundamental, or get a kick to punch right, or make space below a bass gtr for a synth bass, etc.. It’s a habit I’ve formed to make sure I’m giving myself the maximum possible headroom in the low end, especially since I’m primarily working with tracks recorded with microphones, and you can get some wild super sub stuff you’d likely never hear but will clutter things up. And, for low-end elements, I find it can often help focus a sound. Sometimes a kick can sound much punchier and cleaner if you get the filter in the right spot, while retaining or even accentuating the fundamental and punch. Especially if you use a resonant peak on the filter. As far as phase shift… whatever. If it sounds good, it is good! PLUS you can use the phase shift to your advantage to futz with a sound that isn’t 180 degrees out.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I like @BatMeckley’s approach for the mixing portion, but tracking- I’ve got 2 thoughts. 

First of all, the artist I MD for js Brett Young, who has this exact thing going on. I have to tank 2.7 in his voice. Like TANK it. Dynamic dips in series 3 or 4 times, plus a dip in the eq on the way in. Remember EQ is just volume, so finding other areas to boost will help balance as well. Find that fundamental and turn that up, should help balance.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
So for this song I was hired to produce and mix it. I got the stems from the demo and did the production in ableton. Then vocals were recut in London and I was sent a Pro Tools session. I always cut and edit in Pro Tools, so I used this session to comp and arrange the new vocals, but then I wanted to just bring it back into ableton and blend with the existing production. So I bounced the vocal from Pro Tools dry  (no verb or delay) but with tuning and some compression and EQ. Then I used some of the demo vocal and some of the new vocal in the final mix.

I'm pretty comfortable committing eq and compression on my vocals (the confidence of years of doing this... ps you should do it more, it's good for the workflow). But if I needed to go back for some reason I could go back to the Pro Tools session. I think I did go back once to remove tuning on an ad lib that was part singing, part talking. 

I'm getting much more comfortable mixing in ableton. The only thing that really sucks about it is that the sessions do tend to slow down when there's TONS of vocals with autotune inserts (the equivalent number of tracks and autotune instances in pro tools does not tax Pro Tools nearly in the same way). So thus far the only way that ableton really works for me to both produce and mix in is if I don't have raw vocals in there. Hence, bouncing from pro tools works best anyway.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I totally hear where the haters are coming from. The Pro-Q interface and mouse controls are infinitely preferable.

What I like about a channel strip is that it limits what I can do, and therefore what I can think about doing. I like being reminded that countless great records were made with just these things and some choice outboard, and that I should be able to do the same. 

Obviously modern record making goes beyond that, but a lot of the time I can accomplish in that one instance what might turn into a mind melting chain otherwise. 

I also enjoy mind melting chains. Don’t get me wrong.

author: BatMeckley
content:
“Dynamic EQ sucks” is a verifiably and objectively bad take, especially out of the blue. 

“I can’t get dynamic eq to sound 🔥 even though it’s a first line tool for a majority of professional mixers and producers” is a not bad take. (See my comments on sm57s and neve pres).

Some poor kid is going to be scared off one of the most useful crayons in the box just cause you can’t get it to work for you. Dynamic eq doesn’t suck.

author: NoahNeedleman

Tbh I find them mostly helpful when used like VCAs. There was a time I put ☝🏻 vibe plug-in (like a UAD EQP1a without any knobs twisted) to do an ITB summing thing, but I think that biggest thing I learned from it was proper gainstaging, and how headroom effects the whole picture. 

I wouldn’t try to adopt a complicated buss-processing scheme if you don’t already do it. It’s problematic at best and deeply convoluted at worst.

author: Josh Bowman

Use some sort of match eq/plugin doctor/etc to figure out the eq curve of the tape plug with your settings and replicate that with regular eq and then compare. On the buss I often really just wanted the eq and not the actual “tape” stuff when I’ve done this and compared the two or lived with the eq curve and then tried to go back to the tape plug.

author: chrissorem
content:
It’s such a strange thing, the longer I’ve done this, the less I think about these sorts of things. . It’s like working on a painting. I’ll think to myself maybe it s need more blue or less grey but never do i think, does this painting look really good?  More so, that my instinct telling  me if its working or not working.(feel) 
References in this scenario,  have never been helpful for me. I’ve tried and always feels like I’m cooking with someone else’s ingredients.  But references have been very helpful when I work out side of my own room. When everything is foreign it helps  me understand the room when I playback music I’m familiar with. 
That all being said when I’m done with a pass of the mix often I’ll have my own  notes the next day that tend to be more technical and many times when I try the technical notes it doesn’t always feel Better. So I suppose that’s when I think about it.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, this is where the difference is between good and great gear. I find if you get the right mic/pre combination, the esss problem is a lot more manageable. I’ve used the pencil technique before and was surprised how effective it was at taming esses and plosives, but it was a scenario where I couldn’t reach for another mic. Also angling the capsule slightly can help, but you have to be careful not to get the singer outside the pickup pattern. Much like micing an acoustic, you can do some real Eqing just by angling up more towards the nose or down towards the chest. I tend to like a vocal mic a bit lower than most people seem to put it. 

Also, @NoahNeedleman  can attest, if I’m in the session I’m proactively fighting against S lyrics, especially if you’ve decided that that’s the sound you want to aliterate in a verse. Straight to songwriting jail. 

Also, like Noah said re: eq ing esses, you can usually see on pro q3 the shitty part of the ess and eq it out… because it also tends to be a combination of the singers resonance and the mic resonance, it’s almost always the same across all of the esses in any particular track. Make a quick preset and just go to work.

author: bryan cook
content:
check out an ever so slightly delayed distortion so you get that diction *and* the hair, just later hair. i like memory man to sansamp. the dark memory man fuzzes up well. I like to push the “punch” lower mid eq before the sansamp gain stage and then roll off bass and treble on the sansamp as well. sometimes lpf and hpf the memory man / sansamp after the fact. making this dirty slap midrangey really helps it not compete with the real or good sounding vocal and fulfill a different role.

delayed distortion can kind of be like predelayed verbs. keeping it forward and getting the vibe stuff. best of both worlds.

author: junior.frigo
content: Hey all! Got a quick tip for a noise reduction technique. Occasionally, I'll get a lead vocal in with too much background noise. But applying noise reduction across the entire frequency spectrum can reduce clarity, which I really want to maintain in the lead. SO. If you grab the brush tool in RX you can hone in on the most audible parts of the noise and create "fade-ins+outs" of noise reduction, maintaining top end clarity in your vocal but masking noise at starts, stops, and ends of phrases. Can be a real life-saver, Cheers!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The number one myth that prevails about EQ is that we want to do the narrowest cut (high Q) possible. In reality it’s the opposite, we want to go as wide (low Q) as we can without breaking things

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
IME, generally speaking, considering it’s gonna get mixed again and paired with other live elements, more focus on eq less on compression, very careful with ambiences. (Verbs in an arena are gonna be useless, but using tracks to add depth to the whole mix is a big argument for having them in the first place.) Tight performances, but very careful on 2&4 information cause flams with the live snare will be VERY noticeable, so snare help needs to live either above or below the live snare… 
It’s all about supporting the live elements, so stems from the mixer are rarely as good as audio files from the producer or even better, retracked elements for consistency of sonics from song to song. 
This is where I lean when mixing/recording/compiling live tracks for artists.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I know a lot of folks here have been anti-dynamic EQ in fabfilter, but I genuinely love it for VO and vocals in general. It allows me to balance the low end or low mids without it sounding scooped or too wooly. It balances from word to word, almost like "Soothe" claims, but without being as destructive. I can boost low end without it having a static low end wooliness.

I don't use it for much other than that, sometimes I'll do it for a low end boost on snare with a tight Q. but those have been game changing uses for me.

author: JustinLeu
content: That's correct, MB introduces crossovers every time, where as you would get the choice of filter type with the dyn EQ. I tend to use MB more because of the time controls...there are dyn-eq that offer that as well though, but out of habit I go to the MB...also to me it is very simple to split the bands and quickly get results. They are acting in the same way, the MB is grabbing the highest peak in what ever frequency range it is looking at ( which is always a moving target). If you were to make a preset on a dyn-eq  that replicates a MB comp (by using low/high shelf + a bell or 2) it would also introduce phase shift. I don't consider either problematic to work with, just always be aware if it is helping or hurting the end goal. If it sounds good it is good.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I went down a crazy deep rabbit hole about why different EQ’s sound different and after reading a dummy amount of math papers it now makes sense to me. The bonus is that after knowing what to listen for it becomes easier to distinguish and you can choose different EQ’s for different tasks more intelligently. 

In short, when a developer is designing a filter they have to balance between a bunch of different math trade offs. Different math decisions will get you different amounts of ripple, ringing, attenuation, phase delay vs group delay differential, etc. Every compromise imparts a different kind of shittiness. 

To hear two filters that are optimized for absolutely opposite aspects, pull up cleansweep, lowpass something pretty hard, and switch the LPF back and from being a chebyshev filter to being bessel filter.  

With eyes open one would be tempted to explain the differences entirely as being related to the amplitude ripple differences, but with eyes closed instead of just looking at the filter diagram you’ll hear more time domain smearing in the chebyshev as well. 

I’m planning on making an educational video on filter topologies if I can ever get around to it.

author: peterlabberton

author: cian riordan
content: Be realistic with what you’re working with. Both of those instruments are difficult to record properly, and featuring the acoustic nuance of a shitty sm57/Scarlett cello performance won’t do the song justice. I often find I’m compensating for un-ideal mic’ing in un-ideal rooms. I’m doing big midrange scoops to hash out resonances. Driving them into realistic spaces to get the dimension right. Sometimes saturating the source, sometimes saturating the space. The space is everything with orchestral instruments. Every now and then you get a good section in a great room playing a beautiful part and you don’t do a damn thing because it already makes the song.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Did an absolutely wild dialogue rescue with spectre this week. 

Got this podcast vocal that sounds like it was recorded through a laptop mic into a web browser recording system that had really strong AI noise suppression and had crazy amounts of packet loss in the transmission on top of all of that. Basically 2k for days and almost nothing else and everything sounded grainy. 

So I pull up spectre and lightly boost everything except for 2k by just a quarter of a dB and then set the dry/wet to around 90% (didn’t look at the number) so you’re almost exclusively hearing that new information. It ended up sounding pretty close to decently recorded vocal and no amount of EQ would have gotten us anywhere near that close.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

I’ve got an eq after the comp all the time. I’m more using my pre-eq comp to shape how the compressor responds (if that makes any sense). Ie high passing it to get rid of low end rumble from triggering the comp or handling a spiky resonance that’s mucking about with how the compressor responds.

author: Matt Huber
content:
What Josh said has been super helpful for me. 

Also, an easy thing to forget is level matching. Most tape plugins by default making things a bit louder, so make sure to compensate for that. Oftentimes, after level matching, I feel that a lot of tape plugins can make things come across “smaller” or duller  due to the transient rounding and (sometimes) the saturation. 

But also, sometimes those things are THE vibe for the song.

author: chrissorem
content:
I think many elements of creating can  benefit from a technique of a “once over”. Meaning do some work on a particular element whether it’s vocal eq or tuning or editing do a pass on it, leave it alone for a bit knowing there is work to be done and jump to something else. It forces your brain to focus on something else and often something with jump out and you can do an another move.  For me it’s similar to when you can remember a word or a name of something and the more your try to remember that harder it’s gets and if forget about it and then think of something else all
Of the sudden it pops in your brain. I’m always trying to figure ways of getting out to my own way

author: peterlabberton
content: Not sure how helpful this is, but: as I’ve mixed more and more, I think consciously about this less. I tend to try and find 2-3 instruments/vocals that will occupy the main focus of a given song or section, and just put those faders up and try and get them to sound amazing. Then everything else just gets gradually turned up and processed to fit in with or accentuate those primary parts. I’ll often briefly solo them to high pass and usually subtly low pass, then sneak the fader up and not touch any solos again. Getting a track a little too quiet, and then hunting around with Spectre, an API style EQ, or Sie-Q for a pleasing frequency to accentuate works well for finding a spot in the frequency range. Also I will often aggressively scoop out low mids on sampled/software instruments as I find these almost always have way more weight there than needed in even a minimally dense mix. FX may be added at any point along the line: if I know it’ll be integral to the part I’ll pop ‘em on a bit while soloing at first, if not I’ll sneak the effect in gradually with everything else playing. I definitely need to be fairly aggressive with filtering as things get more dense, particularly in the low end.

author: Deleted User
content: I love the conclusion of this discussion. Looking back on mixes I’ve done, there were mixes that effortlessly turned up without being squashed and still felt good and there were mixes that I couldn’t get loud whatsoever. Being able to get balance and competing things out of the way and placing density in the right place is something I’m working on my mixes these days. Low pass filtering surprisingly has been helping a lot. The resonant peak can give presence in intended areas while the filtering also creates room for bright elements to shine.

author: bryan cook
content: I think @Eric Martin is right and just to tag on to this, you can actually hear a little peak on lpf and hpf even when you don’t dial in a resonance, if you have steep slopes. with steep slopes it puts focus on that corner frequency and our ears are drawn to it, even though it’s technically not being boosted.

author: Deleted User
content:
From my experience, mic positioning is the key with getting the clean brightness in vocals. A lot of times I’d put the mic slightly above or below the mouth to have the full spectrum of vocals without accentuation of high mids. The idea is that the voice projects through the mic not to the mic. This allows me to boost natural top end without having to make weird or any cuts on the high mids. Key thing is to keep the pop filter at the same height as the mouth so they don’t start looking up or down to match the height of the mic. That can be detrimental to vocal performance as it strains their neck. 

Sometimes people record too close to the mic. From my experience, it doesn’t take the EQ too well unless you’re intentionally going for the proximity effect to have a little more woomph. If you’re going for that, dynamic mic may be a better choice. 

I would spend some time working with the artists to go over mic positions on zoom before recording. For the vocals that are already recorded, I can’t really say much about what to do because there’s no context, but I’d say try not to over process because that would get things sounding dull very easily.

author: mixedbywong_my
content: Usually 2 days per song. I try to work on 2-3 songs a day . Switching from one song to another . Maybe 2-3 hours a day per song ? With breaks every 1 hr or so (15-20 mins break time or whenever ) if there production issues or something that sticks out real bad I’d ask the producer or artist if we could make it better or find out if it’s intentional so I’m not fixing stuff that’s meant to sound a certain way. Getting a direction or vision goal of what the song should sound like in the end would be really helpful .

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Cian’s note on pokey frequencies is great. I mix banjo a lot (country music,) and I’ve got a couple thoughts that might be helpful if you’re not already finished. 
1) choose the top carefully. Where the “brightness” of the track is changes so much of how it’s perceived in the track. Chances are the top end is actually much lower than you’d expect. 
2) try compressing the shit out of it. Squash it allll to hell, kill the dynamics, RUIN the performance. There’s a good chance if it’s performed well it’ll turn into a punchy percussive element that adds size and excitement. 
3) make sure it’s balanced with another instrument on the other side of the the stereo field. If you don’t have one that’s playing something similar or has a similar top end, give it the old mono-verb/delay and see if that helps balance and keep it from being too distracting.
Hope that helps!

author: cian riordan
content: And if I do HPF and notice an audible phase shift, then I'll try and work around it with shelving or different slopes. You just don't know how it's going to sound until you try it. I'm always pleasantly surprised when -- sometimes -- putting a HPF at 20 or 30hz on a kick drum will actually make it sound punchier. Sometimes it sounds worse. Gotta hear both sides.

author: cian riordan
content: Yeah, I’ll usually save HPF for the whole bus, if even… and use shelves to reign in low end on individual mics.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I personally think everyone should try to master at some point, it informs how you’ll mix if you understand how to get things to sound good at a “finished” level.

For some people that finished level might be -14 for streaming but finding where the EQ profile matches mastered music is the key to unlocking the world of success IMO.

author: cian riordan
content: This has often been my experience as well. I find that the less experienced mastering engineers tend to dig in a little more with EQ and compression and its more of a battle to get it to a place where I'm happy with it. Some people lament when mastering engineers do very little (see the Gehringer/MWTM observations) but that's always my preference.

author: Rollmottle
content: Soothe can be a miracle worker! I've used it to tame resonances in the low mids from bass and synths, annoying ass honk on vocals, and gnarly sibilances. I find it's best used subtly, especially in my use case for correction on a master. I pull it out most often for taming build up and gnarliness in the mid range, especially as it relates to vocals.

author: BillyC
content: IME pops will be more apparent on sustained lower frequency content, but you should generally ramp your 90 degree breakpoints when in doubt. The key command for clip gain is control+shift+x

author: oaklandmatt
content:
yeah but you gotta remember that things sound different a second time or from a different part of the room or whatever. we're all like that. on the flip side, how many times have you been moving an eq, losing your mind being like "i thiiiink that's better" only to realize you're moving an eq on a different track than the one you have solo'ed?

we as the "expert" in these rooms should have the most humility.

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: peterlabberton
content: @Will Melones I’d check out the iZotope Tonal Balance Control meter. My room, with no corrective EQ, gets a little squirrelly below 150-ish, but with some EQ and that plug-in, I’m now able to dial in low end quickly and reliably. It’s pretty easy to see if something is really sticking out—has been clutch for both turning things around super quick on deadlines and also working late/quiet.

author: cian riordan
content: Just stops the compressor from overreacting on the low end material. Very rarely is it better to *not* have some HPF before the comp, even if you’re just snagging subsonic stuff.

author: Deleted User
content: I use the Santa Cruz eq every day. It’s just insane how much smoother/more Hi-Fi it sounds than FabFilter or Izotope EQs

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I don’t suffer from analysis paralysis, but rather trusting my instincts that *more* work needs to be done. 
If I haven’t gotten a part right or figured out the vocal eq quick enough, I start to assume I’m focused on the trees. 

I’m guess I’m saying following your gut and making quick decisions doesn’t always mean finishing faster; trusting that initial instinct and doing the work to follow through with it is the way.

author: BatMeckley
content: Print your reverb. And then do all sorts of shit to it. Saturate it. Eq it. Multiband compress it. Reverb was meant to be mangled

author: David Fuller

author: Nomograph Mastering

content: Or recreate the curve exactly using only additive EQ

author: Eric Martin
content: I’m using 48db HPF slopes a lot actually, sometimes I want to kill all the junk hard and not let any of it color other instruments, especially in heavier, dense music

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
im a bit of an outlier in this regard, but i dont really like spectre for adding high end. Sounds too brittle to me, no matter the distortion type. 

My favorite use for it is adding warmth to sounds in the low mid and lows. I really like the tube mode for this. 

I also fine the higher up the frequency range you go, the more subtle you have to be with the db boosts. I rarely have found myself using anything higher than ~3db with it

author: LAPhill
content: Resonances can exist for a lot of reasons at the source that have nothing to do with bad mixing or tracking even

author: JustinLeu
content: I think something to think about is that  as others have said it is a useful tool in many situations, including creative uses (controlling lowend, side-chain specific frequencies etc.) For modern *LOUD* productions, there is no way to get around having complete control over each source. MB comp/Dyn EQ/De-essers are not band-aids, they are tools to control audio for a more controlled end result. On vocals...you could spend a lot of time automating resonances out (which sometimes is 100% the way to go) or you can put a Dyn-eq on a few freqs and keep working. These tools are incredibly useful for mix engineers that do not get a say in what gets sent to them.

author: Jeremy Klein
content: i use a ton on vocals. Almost every song i mix has parts where the vocalist hits certain words loud in their upper range and it can get a bit harsh at the 2-4k range. if i just straight suck it out with a 5db cut, the vocals lose energy. But if i put a dynamic eq doing -5db, its best of both worlds

author: Adam Thein
content:
I think you are going to get a lot of varied answers about this because it'll be very different from person to person and their mixing style!  The longer I've been at it I tend to do less processing on my submix groups personally, but always have my sessions organized with them for a few reasons:

1) it can be really mentally helpful for me to try and get a track with potentially 100s of individual tracks down to about 10-12 faders for balancing
2) it helps me keep my sessions visually consistent across all the artists I work with and across styles, so I always know where to find things in my sessions regardless of track count or instrumentation
3) it can make it much easier to organize and print stems for an artist after a mix is finished if they are requested

author: Ross Fortune
content:
~~I can’t remember which track, but ~~I worked on Hot Chip’s Bathful of Ecstacy album (mix assistant). Alexis made some last minute lyric changes, recorded new lead vocals on his iPhone and I had to slot them into a verse. Wildest Pro-Q curves you ever seen, split across a bunch of tracks with different EQ and compressors for each word in some cases. I was pretty happy with the results in the end though, pretty imperceptible after everything went through the vocal mix chain.Took ages but it was a good ear training lesson. 

@jantrit ‘s recipe above is a good methodology

*Went back and dug it out, it was second verse of this track - 1:58 "a lot to learn, a lot to earn" was recorded on iPhone https://open.spotify.com/track/2yhKDrTVMCLBWYd0aIfOfy?si=1a2914797e6843d8

It's got a low double and the FX are such a part of the character; it's a context that allows this tomfoolery.


Incidentally, just remembering some other stuff around that record. It was produced by Philippe Zdar (that particular edit was made less than two weeks before his tragic death), and I remember the stems coming in with all of their character baked in. Wouldn't say it's the band's best album, but some of the parts were awesome.

A bass guitar came in with the hihat baked in to it, so I dutifully went back on emails asking for them separated, but that was how he'd printed it - they were sharing some piece of gear, and for whatever reason that's how they had to go down. Mark Ralph was mixing it, and at the time I might've had a bit of a "huh, Zdar's supposed to be a professional, why is the hi hat on the bass channel" sort of bullshit attitude, but that particular instance cleared that right out. Mark's response to anything like that was always pure acceptance and understanding that people work how they work and it's his job to do what he can with whatever he receives.

author: Jeremy Klein

I use FabFilter Q-3 but, yeah as @Edward Rivera said, I cannot imagine any modern stock eq wont be good enough for resonant eq dips. 

If the sound is changing too much and sounding weird, thats almost certainly a result of the eq move itself and not the plugin.

author: BatMeckley

author: LAPhill
content: Gullfoss was really handy when mixing the whistling from the session last week. I used it subtly, and reduced the frequency range that it was affecting, but it did a great job of knocking down all sorts of weird resonances and overtones. Soothe probably could've done something similar, but I don't have it. IME "Tame" at about 10% is all you need for it to clean things up without causing problems. "Recover" usually doesn't do anything good.

author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to match stuff by ear is a great learning opportunity (not trashing EQ match). Recently was trying to punch in vocals on half a bridge on a song recorded a year earlier in a different studio with a different engineer on a different mic. Just AB'ing back and forth and going, "ah, yep, it's a little brighter in the old recording..." and then poking around and trying to find out the right spot to boost... going back, "okay, now it feels a little boxy..." etc. etc.. When you get down to it, things are usually simpler than you think. It's bright, it's dark, whatever. You address it, and learn/train your ear in the process. And if you're a little lucky and kinda know what you're doing, often you can get pretty close pretty quick. 🙂

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I struggle with this sometimes. My instinct is to make everything explosive, generally in a fairly heavy handed manner. I’ve occasionally tried to temper that instinct and gone in with kid gloves, but whenever I’ve ignored the Smash Smash Demon on my left shoulder, I end up wasting the day making overly subtle moves that add up to “completely fine” mixes. 

I listen back the following morning, think “fuck this”, smash the everliving fuck out of everything as I should’ve done in the first place, and end up with a much more satisfying and engaging version.

Obviously it’s horses for courses, and how the material comes in is going to dictate what needs doing, but I’m starting to think that this instinct to energise / grab attention / inflate to larger-than-life proportions might be my USP. This is what all of my mixes that I still like seem to have in common (apart from sounding shite).

Beyond my own little therapy session here Noah, this post is intended to suggest that “gently gently” might not be the way (not having heard the track of course), and maybe the move is to juice *everything* up a couple of notches. Juiced gtr might sound “processed” in comparison to the current flat drums, but if you juice the drums up too, and then the bass, the contrast might not be so apparent. 

Let us know about the outcome.

author: jonmatteson
content: yesterday i felt like having fun with the shawn everett style of mixing on a demo and trimmed down 10db, added a few tape machine plugs, pultec, and gained a vintage limiter up to make up for the gain and it was super fun to mix into. I know this is not the best or most efficient way of working but it was fun to throw the rules out and be broad stroke creative and it definitely injected a lot of vibe into the track that i wouldn’t have been able to get on individual elements.

author: peterlabberton
content: I've had some good results from time to time just being ruthless cutting the bottom octave with a low shelf. There's usually still *plenty* of sub info, and you rather cleanly accentuate some of the harmonics above the fundamental that way.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I’ve been doing the same thing with my PCM70, cycling through the patches. Sometimes I feel that what I like is that those patches are a little bit over the top but I never bother to edit them because it’s a PITA to do. Maybe with plugins we have too many opportunities to tweak em to “blend” in the mix when the opposite might be better.

Here are a few things I like to do with vocal FX:
- Chorus / Doubler that I then distort and will boost some high mid frequency (spectre is great for that)
- mono slap back is underrated, can be very appropriate in modern mixes
- Mentioned many times but compressing / distorting / EQing reverb returns (side chaining the compressor in the return with the dry vocal as key can really make vocal reverb bloom)
- Also, I don’t always tempo sync my delays, sometimes 300ms just works 
-

author: chrissorem
content: One idea is to duplicate the key track with no output.group them together so when you solo or mute they work together. This also can be helpful because you can treat the sidechain “trigger track” as needed for its function.. for example if it’s a hit hat that you want to trigger the key you can gate it to be more staccato

author: Nomograph Mastering

Better advice is find a bass player who can play properly to clean up the low end! Better yet is get decent monitoring so you actually meet the record and hear the effect of these filters. Default always high passing or the opposite is not ideal

author: Rob Domos
content: A lot of that over processed sound is actually exactly what I’m trying to avoid with this approach. I don’t need to have a bunch of dynamic EQ and multiband compression and multiple db of de-essing etc. when what is really needed is a quarter db move here or there where the mic is shitting out in one way or another, and the way the mic is shitting out changes from note to note. I actually think it’s the “catch all” processing like soothe and gullfoss that I’m removing with this approach that is causing the unnaturalness you’re not liking.

author: BatMeckley
content: The first positive step is realizing we don’t really HEAR 30hz per se. It’s only really felt. What most people associate as hearing 30hz are really upper harmonics much higher in the frequency spectrum. No amount of turning up 30 hz is going to make it more audible in the context of a track.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Why are some singers/mics so fucking hard to de ess? 

I have a few singers, usually female, that send me vocals where the esses are sharp enough to poke out my ear drums, and seemingly no amount of de essing will tame that without then making them lispy?

Not just loud esses, but little peak resonances at like 9 or 11k, rarely in the same place. And by the time I’m done doing them manually I’m ready to quit mixing altogether.

author: Jonathan Jetter

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Sure- I think a few things. 

- The low likelihood of opening the session exactly (various plugins, like Joe said).
- I'm not doing any secret sauce most of the time, not much for esoteric techniques. Just really meticulous balancing, framing, polishing, largely *because* the larger moves have already been done. Not every producer is able to switch hats and approach their sounds the way I do (though of course some can). But my bigger concern is that I'm not sure they *should* take themselves out of the producer mindset, I think it can sometimes stifle the process.
- Not everyone I work with has monitoring that allows them to focus on the small moves the way I do.
- The amount of clip gain, volume automation, EQ automation, RX work, etc that I do......it'll take people a *lot* of time to do it if they're not used to doing it every day.
