author: montrose recording
content: whether accurate or not my comment came from spending a week with shawn at mwtm a few years ago - he seemed to have a thought process he could explain behind all the moves.  sometimes conceptual like eq matching guitars to a clash stem,  or using harrison eq plugin bc it reminded him of thriller.   it was super informative to watch him do 1-2 hour mixes of 15 different peoples random projects - he would create a narrative of where it should go as a concept via either a reference or impressionistic image and get there.  and was able to pretty easily explain that process to 15 students

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I'm in a Saturn phase. It was boring until it wasn't. The precision of the drive control lets you hit the balance between color + transients any way you want.

Also one of the few spots I play w/ M/S. Maybe like 20% of the time, when the M is already driven enough on the tracks/buses and the S isn't (like a lot of verb returns + synth pads all piling up), Saturn on the S is like cheating.

Often just EQ --> Saturn --> Limiter here. Sometimes other stuff.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I can't speak for anyone else but the LF resonance on many amp sims (and many real bass amps...) leads to giant mess at 80-150, give or take. I'm sure there are ways around it but I just usually search for other solutions over here.

author: Rob Domos
content: One key thing that helps this work that might not be obvious is that the pitch is pretty loose. Sometimes big stacks on the same part being tightly tuned turns into phase city and makes frequency holes that move around. You could be experiencing that?

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I love using the Culture Vulture, Sketch Cassette, Echoboy, Decap. Unless it’s an obnoxious punk track i’ll usually turn the track up loud and then notch EQ or multiband some of the nastier pokier frequencies out of the vocal. Always love the way Flood treats PJ Harvey’s voice and the distorted vocals on Deerhunter’s Nicolas Vernhes produced albums.

author: Julia Borelli
content:
Hey everyone! I’d love to hear how you organize your schedules and your workflows, especially when it comes to mixes and revisions. I’m mixing and mastering, and I have a manager and an assistant. We’re constantly trying to improve our workflow, but some weeks are so busy that it’s hard to keep balance, and I end up overworking.

Here’s my current workflow: I use Asana for project management to keep track of all projects. When something is booked, my manager adds it to Asana, and I assign it to my assistant to prep the mix session for me. Once it’s ready, we schedule it in. I try to do one mix a day (sometimes two..) and then handle masters and revisions for previous projects in the afternoon. But this often gets moved around because mixes or revisions take longer than expected.

For those of you managing multiple projects, what’s your delivery time like for mixes and revisions? How do you schedule how long a mix will take? How do you decide how many mixes to do in a day while still keeping a clear mind?

Another issue I’ve been facing is communication. Some artists text me on WhatsApp, others on iMessage, Telegram, email, or Instagram. I’ve tried centralizing to email, but it’s impossible. So I keep all revision notes on the Notes App in a folder to keep track. I try to do ‘Inbox Zero’ but it’s not easy. How do you deal with managing communications across so many platforms?

Sorry for so many questions, haha. I just had a burnout and was a brainless zombie for two weeks. I’m trying to optimize so it doesn’t happen again 🥴

Any tips, tools, or advice would be super helpful!

Thanks so much! 😊

author: chrissorem
content: This is interesting, I do agree there are  often times decisions aren’t being made. I find that this is a side effect of everyone having the ability to be able to record from their home or wherever. It’s becoming more rare to have a record made with the traditional producer/engineer team working on a record From beginning to end. It’s more common a band will come in and track basics take it home for a few weeks try a bunch stuff out in their untreated room where they really can’t tell if they are adding something to the arrangement that’s muddying up a the song or if it  needs a different mic, positioning or eq ect. Or if in fact  it’s an orchestration issue.  Regardless they add it and send it to a mixer and say it sounds shitty because it hasn’t been mixed yet.  This is where I disagree with the whole “they’ve been living with it for however long so just make everything better than what they had”. Serban says somewhere down the line decisions haven’t been made. So even though I might get push back I’m going to try to do whatever  it is I think will make the mix better even if it’s crossing over into  the role of production. I can always give them back what they had but often the mix needs some things muted and calls for some big moves when the scenario above happens. I know some productions are not this case and require light lifting but in my world that hasn’t been the case.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Certain group processing is easy, e.g. an EQ on a group is mathematically identical to the same EQ on each individual track.

Certain processing (e.g. Autotune) has to be monophonic in order to work right

Certain processing (dynamics, distortion) is very situation-dependent. And the more complex the chain, the more situation-dependent it becomes. And the linear processing (e.g. the EQ, but also most reverbs) then becomes different depending on whether it's before or after the nonlinear stuff.

author: Rollmottle
content: Loudness doesn’t come without tradeoffs and only you can know what the right trade offs are for your music. Limiting can certainly degrade the listening experience if done poorly. Your theory that limiting inherently degrades the listening experience because there are “artifacts” is voodoo. Being laser focused on artifacts that are only audible upon going out of your way to listen for them with a high pass filter is getting a bit lost in the sauce. I’d take a step back and focus on getting the music to feel good, not whether somebody might find limiting artifacts in your music if put under an electron microscope. Alternately, you can also simply make quieter records.

author: ALXCPH
content: I wouldn't. Low cutting a sound that does't have any low-end can actually do more harm than good.  You can try it your self. Find a sound that sounds like you want it to, that doesn't have any low ned problems. now try a do a High-pass filter and look at the peak meter. It will most likely peak higher than it did before, with no audible benefits. Only do a High-pass filter, if you need to remove low-end, thats creating a problem or taking up space. low cutting to *be safe* is generally not great practice. Also if you do a lot of low cuts, vary the cutoff points or you will get a build up of that frequency. Lets say if you low cut everything at 100Hz... you will end up with a bump at 100Hz. So just be weary of that. 😇

author: BillyC
content: It's mostly about keeping phase in mind and not working against the bleed. If there's vocal bleed in the guitar mic then the guitar mic is part of your vocal sound and vice versa. Before doing anything, it's usually worth zooming in and sliding the regions around a bit to see if you can improve their phase relationship at all. Then you can try to use EQ in a way that best preserves that relationship with the least harm done to the overall vocal sound. I've had good results with keeping any HP/LP filtering on the sum and using only bell filters on the individual stems.

Hey!

I have Tonal Balance set to the Fine mode, with the Modern curve preset, and with 5 second averaging instead of the default 10. I use it in the last 10% of the mix usually - when I'm at the OK my body is moving, the balances are close, I've got some automation to do but let's see where I'm at on Tonal Balance. I don't really use it while mixing, but more of a problem solver.  One thing I'll do is if I do see a clump of something somewhere I'll start muting tracks that are in that range to see if a single source is causing the lump or it it's a broader number of sources. author: JustinLeu
content: A few things I've found helpful is setting up my mix sessions with many points of control--- VCAs for all groups and then more specific (*All Music* *All Drums* *Kick/Snare* *All Vox* etc...) then a master fader controlling how hard I hit the 2bus. Starting with the biggest section of the song helps as well. I can then automate the other sections up or down *including the master fader feeding the 2bus*  As far as clipping/limiting on sources/busses I find it good to shape the sounds how I want (more heavy lifting) then the busses/2bus end up just glueing it together with a lighter touch. I think the 2bus doing too much of the lifting is where it can start to fall apart.

Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand. 

AVOX duo is a neat trick I use sometimes to help give a vocal some dimension. I use it on a send.

author: sukhuno
content:
Yeah dude - it has essentially all of the features of ValhallaDelay already built in... so how i do it is I find the right time pocket (1/4, 1/8, etc) and then set it up in a rack. Then i will mess w the EQ settings of the delay signal to give it the right freq content. I personally only use the ping pong and stereo modes (never really use the M/S). 

Then in the third tab i set up the ducking  and mess with the threshold and release settings to duck out of the way of the lead. I love the sound of the echo swelling up after the phrase is done so i'll usually start at -15 for theshold and ~100ms for release and experiment from there. that third tab also has noise, gate, and a wobble option to add some more character. Then just like the diffusion setting in valhalladelay - you can use the reverb and decay settings to add verb to the delay signal pre/on feedback/post in the chain to give it more softness/space. 

But the killer feature is then you can modulate these settings in the 2nd tab... then i add a little percentage change to one side of the ping pong delay ~1.3% so it's not completely locked in and just adjust settings from there. on the first page, you can also drive the input super hard to get a distorted sound and bring down the output level (like a preamp). It's super versatile and you can get big swelling verb echoes or overdrive space echo type sounds.

author: jantrit
content: Never having tried eq match I can’t talk on that but I’ve had good luck doing an ‘eq match’ myself on a number of occasions. Pick the one mic you want to replicate and slap an eq on the other. Listen between both and just use your ears to get as close as you can until it’s not an issue anymore.  More often than not you can get them close enough that no one will be able to tell. Start with broad strokes “this one has more low end” boom add some low to the other. Then slowly starting to narrow in making smaller and smaller adjustments until it feels right.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason that analog synths have so much more solid of a lowend than any digital synth. It’s not the saturation giving you that solidity. It’s that hardware LPFs don’t have anywhere near the same amount of cascading delay differential. I.e. a software bass synth by default has a slight reverb that is phase canceling itself wellllllll into the passband (like all the way down iirc) just by the nature of it having a digital LPF bottlenecked at 44.1, where a moog filter has very little of that going on because the sample rate of the real world is infinite, or the speed of light, depending on how you look at it.

author: cian riordan
content: This “pre-gain staging your template” thing sounds like you’d be backing yourself into even more trouble. Templates are meant to be flexible and you’ll always need to make adjustments to make things work for the track. Let’s say you calibrate your drum bus for 1 dB of gain reduction — what does that do to account for the overall mean volume of those drums? The frequency density? It’s such a weird esoteric metric to try and quantify the signal you’re sending through it. Best thing you could do is setup your template to be able to do broad stroke gain adjustments within, very quickly, to get your chains hitting the way you like.

author: Rob Domos
content:
There are a lot of things that you’d usually want to fix regardless of any considerations in the track. Ie. Crazy plosives, mouth smacks, jacket rustling, mic stand bumping, noise fades, etc. I’ll typically get these janitorial fixes done without much thought of the context, (with the exception that I know to leave in a little more lip smack if it’s an aggressive rhythmic track than I do if it’s a ballad).  Beyond that my main thought is that I don’t want to hear the microphone. ie. mechanical sounding capsule buzz is something I tend to attenuate. 

All of this happens without me being able to hear the instrumental context (though I wish I could. RX integration into a daw context would be a game changer for me). 

Ruairi will rebalance the harmonics in a vowel, and while I also do that some in a vocal prep context, it’s harder because the undulation of resonances in a full musical context sometimes feels exciting while in solo it sounds off-putting. Ruairi gets to have the whole song in his RX window where I’m often only hearing the vocal, so I have to be a little more careful to imagine context and hedge my bets Hippocratic oath style, lest it looses some life.

author: chrissorem
content: It depends but two things come to mind. One would be that I want to vocal to feel upfront but I want length  I tend to darken with a shelf anywhere from 2-5k. Reduce to taste. I prefer to do this before the reverb usually.  The other thing that comes to mind is verbs can take up quite a bit of space, so  one way to listen for it is to turn the send up to taste and then mute it.  try and listen for what tonal changes are happening when it’s unmuted. And take away masking frequencies.  Some instances I boost frequencies  on the fx  return, this allows it to poke out where it can be heard and I can turn it the return down a bit.  Does that make sense ?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
To expand on this...I think he thinks that most of the sounds he's receiving are about 90% finished. So his little EQ notches + 1-2dB of compression get to the finish line. And I think part of the reason it works for him is that he's probably right, obviously he's at a level where the productions are professional, and again obviously his mixes bump hard.

But I also think there are situations out in the world where sounds are 100% finished and those moves would be a step back. And obviously many situations where sounds are nowhere near 90% finished and need a heavier lift from the mixer. So if your producer clients are at a different place, then you'll need to be at a correspondingly different place to still add up to 100%.

He’s of course smart enough and skilled enough to perceive what’s what.

author: Jonathan Jetter

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you've got the *Valhalla Supermassive* I like to make a faux room sound by cranking the *feedback* up to 75%, dialing the *delay time* down to around 9 ms and maybe *warp* at 50%. It's a much more synthetic, and chorus-y sound, but blends well with just about anything.

The cool thing about *Supermassive* is that there's so much heavy modulation on the delay lines that you don't get a lot of nasty ringing or notches that you'd get with most delays at that short of a delay setting.

author: Juliette
content:
It is so so so rewarding to witness the progression of your mixes over the course of a several years. It's such a great way to show yourself that you are indeed learning how to navigate the soundscape, as well as remind yourself that you are getting better, slowly but surely.

When I first started, I used to watch and listen to hundreds of hours of podcasts and videos with all kinds of musicians and genres and engineers, and the words all sounded like total spaghetti. I got frustrated because I would mimic their EQ curve and my songs wouldn't sound good. It's quite nutty how your brain starts to pick up on those certain tidbits and figure out what's poking out, what sounds good to *you*, and so on. It's such an art form.

author: Slow Hand
content:
That’s the big hangup for me and many plugins that have skeumorphic interfaces made to look like the hardware: the controls are clunky and slow when used with a keyboard and mouse. They’re designed for hands and dont translate well to computer controls.

On the other hand, you have tools designed for computer like Pro-Q that are butter-smooth and intuitive with a mouse.

In the case of SSL EQ plugins, maybe the solution is to add an *x/y mode* where you can hold a key and then the freq knob controls both gain on the y-axis and freq on the x-axis.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Sure! RX is using FFT based processing.  (Worth googling and doing a deep dive if anyone is unfamiliar)

As a general rule with FFTs (and with EQ!!), the more narrow a selection is in the frequency domain, the wider it is time domain. This is an inviolable math law we can’t get around. 

How many bands the FFT is using has big implications for this, because the more bands there are, the more narrow the frequency impact can be, which means the wider the time impact has to be. 

You can make what looks like a very short selection in the time domain in RX, but if the FFT selection is set to the maximum amount of bands, you’re going to be effecting a ton of information to the left and right of your selection. Similarly, you can select just one narrow frequency but if you have the minimum amount of bands selected you’ll be turning down a whole bell the size of a half an octave

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: Rollmottle

author: mixedbywong_my

author: Adam Thein
content:
If retracking is still an option maybe that's the ideal solution, but three things that come to mind to me to try if it's pretty extreme is pulling up the audio in RX and using the lasso tool to just track that sweep (it should be pretty visible and consistent if it's bad enough you are automating an EQ to duck the resonance) and just gain that down enough to be able to use other tools more effectively).  Another thing I'd try if you have it is soothe2 if you can get it to mostly work on that resonance without killing the tone (even maybe these both in combination) and then finally I'd try something like Saturn or Kclip in multiband and try and use a combination of dynamics and saturation within that band to tame it further.  If it's really bad maybe a combination of those 3, or just automating an EQ but that sounds grueling and time consuming if it's throughout the entire performance.  Maybe Surfer EQ could also accomplish this but I don't have that plug.  I also think there's a Surfer EQ type function in Nectar or Neutron?  Somebody that knows Izotope's stuff better than me can probably chime in.

My 2 cents and probably there are some better solutions out there but this is where I'd start personally!

author: Adam Thein
content:
A huge majority of the work I do is tracked at home by indie artists and I'm often wearing a lot of hats with a "mix" that can vary from a track that hits my inbox completely edited (timed, tuned, audio cleaned) and I can sit down and mix a track in one sitting (2-3 hours) before I feel good about sending it off.  That situation for me almost always involves programmed drums or drums printed by the artist with a committed sound.  However, that being the ideal I can also be completely transforming and recovering tracks that arrive with tons of noise, resonances, artifacts, clicks, multitracked drums not phase or time aligned, sloppy super dynamic playing etc, vocal timing and tuning.  On that side it can take days and days, weeks and weeks, or even months off an on depending on the artist and track count.

My advice on projects like that #1 is make sure you are negotiating your rate based on the extra work expected of you and #2 try and compartmentalize so that you are doing all the dull tedious work separate from the creative mixing.  Take a lot of breaks, and make sure you are communicating with the artist to manage expectations on why things are taking more time.

author: Maxim
content:
It depends on the song but a lot of times you don’t actually want to “hear” the reverb. It should be woven into the performance in a smart way and that’s where choosing the right verb and EQ is essential. 

So I’m not sure if there’s really any “secret” other than developing your ears to hear what’s right and knowing how to get there. 

If a client is asking for “more reverb” I wouldn’t take that literally. Maybe they want to hear more reverb between phrases (automate or use ducking), maybe they want a verb that has more high-end information (plates tend to sound a bit dull unless EQed), maybe use multiple reverbs at different lengths with various characters to compliment each other, etc. etc.

There’s really too many options to give a general response.

But as far as getting the vocal upfront use pre-delay and slap delays to get that width. Dial in the MS amount by ear.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Multiband Comps are legit voodoo. I’ve been working with ProMB for a year and only now starting to feel ok about it. Couple things:
1) sometimes your mixed is well balanced, but overall lacks or has too much of a certain area, so a multiband can help address intermittent problems  without destroying the whole area of a mix like eq might. 
2) dynamic eq > multiband UNTIL you want to address attack & release times 
3) crossover / phase issues scare me, and trying to understands them technically before just using the ProMB just gave me analysis paralysis. 
4) try some of the basic presets on your plug, gain match, and then do the blind toggle test. Easy and takes no time at all.

author: NoahNeedleman

It was all just clearer what was going on in mixes I loved. But assuming you’ve got a great listening experience, the next thing I had to learn was who lives in that region best. It’s different for every mix, but choosing who gets the focus in those regions helps a lot! Also 1-5k is such a big range. Thinking of 1-3 and 3-6 separately might be helpful too! Just a few ideas that have helped me achieve mixes/productions that I like.

author: Zack Hames
content:
- EQ them differently is a great place to start in mixing.

During recording, you can use a different mic, have the singer back off of the mic more than the lead, etc. I’ve found using a different mic is an AWESOME technique, it’s a must. I started hearing phasing in my doubles and harmonies, especially when you start tuning, different microphones fixed that problem immediately. 

It doesn’t even need to be the best mic - if you’ve only got one “proper” vocal mic, a sm57 might be just fine for the certain things.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
the main thing for phase issues is not hard tuning double/ triples. if you tune things aggressively, they will be pulled so accurately in pitch that they will phase in the frequency range of the note being sung (the fundamental plus some harmonics). 

depending on the type of song, i will either tune doubles less aggressively, or sometimes detune the whole vocal a couple cents within auto tune. you have to LISTEN (of course) and play with the options to see how wide/ chorusy/ flangey you want it to be.

author: Rob Domos
content: The same thing can happen with someone who sings in such a way that they create a lot of these bullshit dense harmonics. The worst offenders usually have their larynx touching their hyoid bone when they sing and have a fuckload of muscular tensions that cause harmonics that resonate at the frequency of the tension of the muscle. Think of it like changing the tension point on a guitar string by placing your finger on a fret to change the pitch, but at arbitrary points set by how tense your muscles are, and each muscle in your neck and face is acting as a mini speaker driver pushing out these random ass harmonics rather than a nice harmonic structure built off of the fundamental. Wallah, this person has the performance equivalent of a cheap capsule

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll bite. Delay lines and feedback loops (the building blocks of a delay unit) have massive utility in audio DSP. With a simple delay unit you can:

Adjust phase relationships
Construct a filter (LPF, HPF, EQ band, etc)
Create echoes
Create chorusing
Create phasing and flanging
Create a tuned resonator
Build a non-granular pitch shifter (think a whammy pedal or a boss shifter)
Build a network of interconnected delay lines and thus a reverb unit

There are plenty more use cases that are slipping my mind right now so.... delay till I die.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I almost never use multiband comp tbh. I use multiband saturation all the time with Saturn.

The general reason i use it is to brighten something without simply adding a high shelf, or to create a broader wider transient on a drum track. The distortion with splay out the sharp transient. So I’ll saturate high end on vocals or bass to get more openness without harsh high end boosts, I’ll use the same sort of settings on close mics on acoustic drums to get more attack and punch. 

This is an Oversimplification but Nothing is bad in excess if it sounds good.  There are no rules.

author: Will Melones
content:
I have two thoughts on this. One is to use balance (often fader automation) to bring attention to a particular track moment by moment. Maybe multiple midrange elements will be competing, but the ear can only focus on one at a time (in addition to the drums, bass, and maybe vocal) so YOU choose and shift the focus!

My second approach is to take two or more of the competing tracks, say kick and bass, and play them together. No point in soloing one. EQ one while listening through it to the other. You may notice that you can subtract quite a bit from the bass without losing its character, but the kick’s punch is improved by the space you’re carving out. I do this a lot with vocals, too—focusing on the vocal inside a dense mix while subtracting from all the other stuff that’s stepping on it. When the lead just finds its home in its own uncongested space, you know you’ve got all the surrounding noise right.

author: Will Melones
content: I don’t think everything can really have its own space in the frequency spectrum, unless you want the mix to sound like a bunch of disjointed band-passed islands floating around

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Having a balanced top end is part of the dark magic of a good mix. I’ve def had trouble with that before. 2 things have helped me a lot. 1) choosing what lives in top super carefully. (Usually vocal & top of the snare are the brightest things in the mix.) 2) using a pultec on the 2buss to give some uniformity to the top end.

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Towards @peterlabberton's point re objectivity and consistency... I recently wrapped up a slightly unusual 3 year "experiment" on myself.

For various reasons, I decided to narrow down variability in my life and rely heavily on routines. It wasn't scientific at all - the journals wouldn't touch it - but I set up a structured life with the same waking and bedtimes each weekday, similar exercise routines, identical breakfast every weekday at 8am (quantities measured), the same salad (Greek, since you asked) every weekday at 1pm for 18 months (then I switched to a tuna salad I liked and stuck with that for 20 consecutive months), and one of four batch cooked dinners at 6:30pm that I would rotate roughly weekly.

[I've started typing this and I'm realising I'd need to spend far more time than I have right now to demonstrate the depth of my findings and their Nobel prize eligibility, so I'm just going to wrap it up semi-flippantly]

Some takeaways:
- When stuff started sounding bad to me like clockwork at 3:50pm every day, I knew it that it was not the mix turning sour - it was just time to eat my 4pm apple. The sugar would kick in, and hey presto, we're back in vibe town. Removing variables can be helpful in diagnosing issues - the diagnostic problem solving approach one develops as a studio assistant can, to an extent, be applied to ones self.

- Limiting variety mitigates decision fatigue and frees up quite a lot of brain power. I like to think of myself as a less dead Steve Jobs - he wore polo necks, I ate greek salads. We both got a lot done.

author: wald
content: Relate with this a lot. I always have a mix like this in the que. Sometimes even good songs , but bad execution as far as rate of information is concerned. Ex a perc part to lift a section, that flams with vocal consonants and unpredictably combines with snare midrange. Millions of examples. The way out for me at least, is to zap the anomalies and unpredictables one by one. Solo mode, out of context, because clearly you can’t mix yet. One by one knock them over. Vocal resonances, consonants, timing, buildups, stacks’ phasing, instrument sections against vocal, etc etc. Make a list even. Might be 3 hours of work, but can save days down the line. The focus will eventually come. Serban’s secret weapon is John Hanes 😂

author: Ross Fortune
content:
+1 on Trigger Gate from Ryan’s recommend.

The Oxford drum gate is also pretty unique in how you can have frequency dependent release - ie the fundamental of the snare can ring on longer, but the crack happens then disappears before the hihat wash becomes over exaggerated 

BX SSL 4k gate can be very precise (and in Fast mode you can use the “snap” as it opens as part of the sound), but I’m in the habit of creating separate gate trigger versions of the kick and snare - super heavily gated (and filtered + compressed) versions of the kick in and snare top. 

I commit the processing on those, mute them but then have them pre fade sending to SC Kick and SC Snare buses. Super handy for lots of functions - either very precise and malleable gate open and close on the audible drums themselves, but also for instrument sidechains, maybe Pro-MB ext input on a bass track, a sine generator under the kick / noise generator on snare, the Slate Trigger feeds etc. 

Having the gate triggers as audio allows you to slide them a couple samples back and forth as needed for groove or faux lookahead. 

Maybe there’s easier ways to do things (it’s a somewhat old school technique), but making them is one of my prep steps and they do get used in every session.

I fuck with dynamic EQ. If I’m doing a large but tight Q boost on say a snare drum, like 15-18dB boost at 150hz or so, it’s nice to only have it actually boost when the snare drum is being hit instead of just a bunch of low end statically swimming.

I also like it for wide Q boosting low end on vocals. Again to balance the low end from phrase to phrase or word to word.

author: NoahNeedleman

So when I’m thinking about glue, I’m mostly thinking about frequency cohesion. Like where is the top of the vocal? How do I get the top of the snare to live there too? Are my perc tracks or BGVs adding density to the sides? Or just motion? Do my bass and kik muddle each other or enhance? It’s almost always an eq question for me…
Of course I never stopped using compression so we may be on different paths. And of course Cian is 100% right. Now that you’ve learned the “why,” it should be very easy to hear what the comps are doing and how to use them to benefit your tracks.

author: chrissorem
content: I do analog summing when I mix so  I have daw  groups that feed final daw  output groups that feed my console. Generally I try to not share fx between groups and designated fx that feed the groups. Example: vocal verb or delays outputs go to vocal group. This give an option to eq compress or saturate and melt together if intended. If I don’t want that I send the fx to their final outputs. Example: vocal verb output doesn’t go to vocal Group but to vocal output to console. This is a good workflow for making stems ect as well.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Agree w/ Ozone Imager. One quirk w/ the MBP though- the center frequency on the Low Mid is actually higher than the High Mid, and the difference is re: bandwidth moreso than frequency there. If you really want to emulate the MBP behavior, play around with the bandwidth of each band, in addition to the plus / minus on the width.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
What does floppy kick mean?

I had good luck with Smack Attack recently on a kick with excessively long low end that hung around after the hit.

Pushing the attack and lowering the overall gain in smack attack worked in that instance, but probably more important was high passing the drum bus so all the flubby stuff sub ~40/50Hz was minimised. I think the filter was somewhere around 60, probably at 12dB per octave. Might sound high in isolation, but it sat well with the bass.

1. I’ve never actually tried it as a final limiter to cap a mix, but I’m not sure it makes much sense to think about it as a “limiter” in that sense. More helpful to think of it as a compressor I think.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I see - what I’m thinking is maybe this step could be working against you - you are essentially forcing all your mics to sum perfectly and you might be ending up with having to do massive eq moves on things that maybe would have naturally been phasing out in a pleasing way for a live room recording.

I’d strongly consider turning off your AA2 plugs on anything that aren’t drums unless it makes it sound significantly worse to you.

I’m a big fan of AA2 but it’s always case by case.  Sometimes the natural phase of the mics can be closer to the result you are looking for eq wise than the perfectly time aligned and phase rotated ones.

content:
I might reframe this a little bit. I know what you're getting at re: U67/Neve/fancy room, but there's also the reality that I've mixed a bunch of vocals from those kinds of setups where the source sound *wasn't* great, sometimes not even good. I'm not sure I have all the answers here but I tend to look at the rough-sounding home studio vocals the same way I look at the fancy stuff, just at a different point on the same sliding scale.

i.e. Which aspects of the sound do I like, which do I not like, how much to change, how much to retain, which tools am I reaching for to make it work, how far can I push those tools w/o causing other harm to the source sound or the vibe of the music. And then it's kind of the same mindset for all of it, just a question of size/scope of my input, and I've found that to be a helpful way to tackle it.

author: James Redfern
content: The original use I found for it years ago was on drum shells, turning the knob to the left acted as a sort of very smooth gate. You could get rid of cymbal schmutz in the top-end/midrange, but let the fatness of the snare decay a little more naturally, or maybe there’s a midrange ringing I don’t want, but I like that frequency on the initial attack, etc. over time it’s just become a tool I turn to for all sorts of stuff. Want the mids of a reverb to decay longer? Want to control the length of certain qualities in room mics? Etc

author: cian riordan
content: So to clarify, I will sometimes use HPF to solve for phase issues between multiple drums mics. The prime example of this is if I have a kit or a room mic that is in phase with the snare drum but out of phase with the kick drum. Sometimes, using the targeted phase shift of a HPF, you can find a way to get both fundamentals to pop into phase on the offending microphone.

author: Rob Domos
content: Often I won’t reverb here where others would. I’ll use EQ to attenuate some of the details and then use something like the stereoize function in the ozone imager to make the left and right less phase coherent which removes some of the clear outline and solidity of the sound, therefor making it feel cloudier and further away

author: spectrummasters
content: Re “how are folks using gullfoss “ ….im defo in cians camp 🏕️ for the main part . I agree , in some ways it seems counter intuitive to use whole spectrum dynamic eq type plug ins imho . Because , they will have a fluctuating phase relationship with the other sounds in the mix that I’m just leaving up to the plug in . This seems a bit reckless after all the cautious phase choices we would make for a mix ? However , I listened recently to a bob horn talk where he described his vocal approach is to do his vocal clean up work , in order to get out clicks , pops , harshness etc and to get out any over heavy lows or low mids  before they go to his first compressor …..but before the compressor first thing on the inserts is gullfoss in tame , no more than 10% and in this position it’s virtually imperceptible and yet does defo do a nice little thing . I tried it and have found it v subtle

author: Ross Fortune
content:
TLDR: Not sure, it breaks when I touch the controls so it’s not straightforward to check 😂

Long version: I got it a few years back and remember at the time cranking the input to see what it did, and it seemed like it did absolutely nothing. The manual says it has auto gain to compensate for altering the input level, but with whatever material I was using I didn’t hear any difference. To the point I actually assumed it was just glitching and the dial didn’t work. 

Moving to a better monitoring environment coincided with a pro tools update where touching any of the Ruby controls during playback causes errors and stops playback, so since then when I’ve used Ruby I just flip it on fairly early on in the process and mix into it with a high and low shelf and “preamp” on. If that isn’t the move, changing the settings is so laborious that I just use the UAD Pultec and dial that instead. Writing this now it sounds ridiculous 😂 But sometimes the gentle smiley curve with the kind of softening effect the “preamp” button has (it sounds like it just dips hi mids around 3k gently) makes things just sound like a record and I keep it on. 

Now I’m keen to check again and see if it does something I just couldn’t hear before. Let me know how you get on with it!

author: jerikcenteno
content:
OH! Thought of two more things that I feel is important to add that ppl might find helpful....

Definitely strip silence/cut out silences in the non-talking audio to get rid of the noise floor, coughs, etc. I do this by hand rather than the strip silence function since the function in PT might delete stuff I didn't want deleted.

At the company I freelance at, they heavily use this app called Descript. You upload your VO's and it builds out a transcript for you. You then can edit the transcript and it'll chop up the audio accordingly. It works better when the VO's are isolated/have no bleed and not recorded in the same room because bleed can mess up the transcription, but if Descript is analzying just one VO at a time, it works great. Then, you can export an .aaf and upload into PT to make fades, mix, etc. Check it out! I've used it too and it's kinda crazy. Prob the only useful AI thing I've come across. 

https://www.descript.com/

author: elvis
content:
So, I’m a long-time follower of this thread, but have been to scared to post any questions as I’m afraid to look like a total dumb ass…

I’m a singer/songwriter/guitarist who has been teaching myself how to record/mix over the past few years. I don’t totally suck, but I have a long way to go.

I’m working on a mix for a client—yes that’s new for me—and I want to kill myself 🙂

Basically, it’s a big, dumb rock song (I.e. Foo Fighters), and I can’t for the life of me reign in the drums—in other words, there’s freaking cymbal bleed in EVERY mic. So, I have this situation where I tame the shitty cymbals—then get something that sounds like kick and snare samples playing along to a vacuum cleaner. Mostly because I’ve put every stinking plug-in like Soothe, multi-band compression and dynamic EQ on the overheads and rooms. Yeah! My cymbals don’t poke your ears out—but, they also sound like a Rumba.

And gating did not work as the drummer is hitting his shitty cymbals on every freaking beat! I ended up sampling a god forgive—clean snare hit and using that as a sample. It’s okay, but without being able to raise the level of the rooms and overheads, I’m kind of fucked.

I found myself referencing this Joel Hamilton production/mix of a Highly Suspect song as it’s kind of similar to what I’m working on. It’s on Puremix. He’s pretty amazing. And while the music isn’t my thing—it sounds awesome. His mix sounds big and organic—while mine sounds like an electric ham sandwich.

Without hearing the song, I don’t know how much advice I can expect. I just mostly want to vent…

I sometimes wonder if I’m the one that sucks, or is it the source material? When do you know you’ve done the best you can with what you’ve been given? You can’t polish a turd. 

And as a newbie dipshit, I’m trying so hard to make whatever I do be super awesome, badass—whatever that means. But, maybe I just need to make the rough mix sound 20% better. I don’t know.

Wow! That was long. Thanks for any advice…

author: Mike Tierney
content: Damn we out here talkin about intonation systems? A lot of my bread and butter is contemporary classical/microtonal/experimental music and I'm in this world as both an engineer and often as a producer keeping track of how folks relate to the score and each other, take maps, etc. I tend to agree with some of the above that trying to chase down inharmonic relationships with EQ can make things worse, but I appreciate @LAPhill posting about bassoon/flute overtone series. @spectrummasters original question was about understanding the low mids and how they relate to EQing depending on the key; I think for me the way that understanding overtone series, tuning systems, and musical interactions in acoustic/orchestral instruments can relate to pop or rock mixing is like... Sometimes when I hear clashes between instruments playing thirds or clashes in the harmonic series and I'm trying to clear space in the mids/low mids, I do think about what instruments want to be occupying that space. So perhaps in the bassoon/flute example, I'd want the flute's fundamental to be stronger than the bassoon's first harmonic at C5, and that might look like EQing down the bassoon in the ranges of the flute's fundamentals, or in a rock mix looking at the bass's harmonics compared to where the lower range of the guitars are living. Obv instruments are moving and changing notes so none of this is surgical so much as the keys of the songs or the instruments' ranges might inform some general decisions about where to make space rather than just "cut 300 on the bass" or whatev

author: Colin Althaus
content: One thing that's been super helpful for me is to assign key commands to the main tools I use in Melodyne. I have it set up so the 1 key is pitch center, 2 is pitch modulation, 3 is pitch drift, 4 is time tool, and I forget what 5 is off the top of my head haha. I always found the right-click-to-change-tool workflow super cumbersome. Having key assignments makes it a breeze. My left hand is on the keyboard changing tools and right hand is operating the mouse at all times. Not sure if something similar has been mentioned already but wanted to share as it sped up my Melodyning drastically!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I like the concept, but I wouldn't ever do it on the master buss because it constricts absolutely everything - not to mention potentially introducing phase-y distortions across the entire mix.

If I'm going to narrow that frequency range I'd do it only on the elements that are calling out to be narrowed in that range. Usually with EQ to darken the panned elements. My master buss ends up being *very* minimal and open to keep me from tying my hands at the end stage.

Then again, I'm also not Luca or Frank. If it works for *them*, cool!

turn all processing off, start over without a bus, use low pass filters and volume first, maybe boost low mids vs top to get the balance you’re looking for.

Don’t be afraid to reamp the amps, and use tape emulations to soften the top end.

and also, let the guitar be pokey, if they came that bright from the artist, it‘a probably how they like they’re guitars to sound

author: earwormfarmer
content: I’ve got nothing against using compression and Eq and that’s typically what I would do for something like this. But this specific case was really giving me a hard time. Lowest note on this upright track was hitting about 7db louder than the higher notes. Sounds like the mic was close up to the body/ f hole and not getting enough of the neck. After trying different EQ + compression techniques, automation just sounded a bit more pleasing to my ears. And made it easier to stick with the up and down dynamics of the song. Which is also very up and down. I could compress then ride a fader to match the track, but either way I’m automating. This song is more in the chamber music world and super dynamic, so EQ / compression moves I would do on other stuff felt more aggressive.

author: wcalebparker
content:
With regard to the “practicing new concepts” thing - for me it depends on the situation. The other day I was working on a live thing and I needed to deal with some bleed. My usual tools weren’t cutting it, so I spent a little time digging into another tool which I thought might do the job well. The deadline isn’t particularly tight so I had the leisure.

I think depending on where you are in your career, it can be really helpful to use someone else’s mixing philosophy as a learning tool, but if people are coming to you for what you do, client projects are probably not the time for that.  

In my head there’s a pretty big difference between exploring a new reverb plug to potentially generate some inspiration and deciding, “on this project I’m SIDE-CHAINING EVERYTHING” when that hasn’t been your thing in the past.

But also, I don’t really think about this that much, and I think you’ll probably have to develop your own feel for what’s appropriate for you. But I wouldn’t  recommend watching MWTM and changing your entire workflow mid project (although I’ve admittedly done this in the past 😂)

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Voxengo Span and TDR Prism are amongst the best analyzers out there, you can actually set them in order to show information about dynamics across the spectrum, but It will not say anything about what you are really doing to the sound when dialing a compressor.

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: cian riordan

author: oaklandmatt

Listen back and forth (actually set it up to toggle it with a click) and play with broad stroke EQ on your current mixes master buss. Find your target with the broadest strokes then go to the individual busses, then into individual tracks as needed.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Whenever I think there's an unpleasant "chirp" in anything,  I create a tight Q band and boost the signal a ridiculous amount (get the eq filter to resonate subtly at the added frequency).  Sweep it up and down until the chirp is amplified more. Once you hear that obnoxiuos sound louder you'll know it.  Then invert the positve gain to a step notch filter.  That way you're not cutting a region. You're cutting the specific pitch of the chirp. Keep all the good of the click. Remove just the bad tone. That's what helps me in these situations anyway.

author: bobby k
content: i’d love to chime in on this! the main real benefit probably has less to do with technical details and is actually a TACTILE detail—trim tools are linear, faders generally seem to move at a curve as they get quieter. (logarithmic curve? opposite of an exponential curve) i don’t know why this is. so say you have a kick drum at -3. you drag your hand down to move it to -4. easy. well that same physical movement would affect a very quiet track at -20 by probably 5-10 dB. you can see this in the print on the fader, the increments get larger as you get quieter. so trimming down -20 then being able to move in similar increments as a loud track is very very helpful.

author: peterlabberton
content: I currently have both a music buss and a vocal buss feeding into the main mix buss. Music has a Kush AR-1 which adds some tubey flavor, vocals get a Fairchild 670, and both only compress a couple dB at most in the loudest moments. Both also have a Kazrog True Iron before compression on the (I think?) “clean master” preset. The mix buss has a Pultec and Slate VTM, then goes to the limiter (Pro-L2). Collectively pretty much every piece of the puzzle adds a touch of saturation and I’ve been liking the collective effect—I did some actual measurement and analysis recently but I don’t think I took any screenshots. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: BillyC
content: At the risk of giving the least satisfying answer possible, without knowing or hearing what is intended in the music I think deep down we all know the answer to this is "when it just feels wrong." And personally I find using reference mixes to be a very slippery slope because they tend to make me question the record in front of me too analytically rather than react to its specific needs intuitively. I instead like to flash some references only at the beginning of the day just to remind myself what good records feel like in my chair before I start trying to make them. I find that whenever I'm asking myself the kind of questions like "do I have enough x, y, or z  frequency range" it's more of a warning sign that I need a perspective break because these questions hardly ever arise in a true creative flow. That's not to say I don't fall into this rabbit hole regularly, I'm just trying to practice what I suspect is a better way out of it!

author: alex_epton

If it’s already stereo try just taking out a tiny bit in the mid channel on a m/s EQ around the frequency of the other instrument you want to highlight. Make the highlighted instrument narrower if it’s stereo

author: Deleted User
content: In my experience, double tracking the exact same instrument - like the same guitar - will usually just end up sounding phasey, not thick and wide. You really really want it to be 2 different guitars, using a different amp or EQ just doesn’t really cut it, I find. And preferably also different amps and maybe even mics on the speakers. The more you’re actually close to something that could literally be an acoustic event(meaning it could play out that way if you were recording both parts live simultaneously), the less phasey it will be. If vocal doubles are too close to the lead sonically, for example, they can end up sounding like a phasey reverb instead of adding punch. So definitely use a different mic. Like, even Freddie Mercury‘s background vocals can sometimes sound a bit one-dimensional because of this, though of course Queen‘s performances were utterly amazing(it usually was just one u67 they tracked with)

author: jantrit
content: A lot of the time I will mess with hard panning diff mono sources in a mix to create the sense of width whilst maintaining balance. Also if it is double tracks like others have said I like to sit them in diff places tonally or treat them differently (diff verbs or pushing diff eq points) it’s the differences in the hard panned sources that create width. When tonally different information reaches each ear at the same time your brain tells you it’s wide! When it’s only subtlety different like in the case of doubles it can end up sounding mono again. A lot of the time I like to pick two elements that are holding it down throughout the track (maybe guitar and Rhodes) and then hard pan those in opposite directions. This maintains the balance left to right.  So I guess try hard panning a mono element and then balancing it out with a totally different mono element the other side.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Convolution is a strange technique to describe in a way that is intuitive to understand. But here goes:

In convolution you have two audio signals, your *input signal* and your *impulse response*. The simplest description of what convolution does is that it multiplies the *input* signal by the *impulse* signal and what it spits out is a new audio signal that includes only the frequencies and amplitude values that both signals have in common.

Practically speaking, what this means is that when you convolve an *input* (let's say, a full frequency drum kit recording) with your *impulse* (let's say a 5 ms burst of white noise that was hi-passed at 500 Hz). What you end up with is a drum recording that sounds like it was hi-passed at 500 Hz.

Think of it like how a vocoder works (which isn't that different). Your vocoder might combine a full-frequency synthesizer patch (input) with the frequency contours and time content of your voice (impulse/carrier). But if your voice doesn't have 100 Hz in it then we never hear the 100 Hz from the synth patch because the input and carrier/"impulse" don't share that frequency. What you hear is what both signals have in common. If your voice has a huge peak at 1.5k, then the synth patch is going to be accentuated in that same way.

So. What I'm saying is that if I have a complex EQ curve (ala Sonarworks corrective EQ) that I use as my *impulse response* and convolve it with, say, the output of my stereo buss, will it impart that frequency curve onto my mix *without* the phase shift that you'd get from a traditional FIR or IIR filter (aka traditional EQs)?

In short, I don't know because it's hard to search for the answer online. But I'm throwing a hail mary in case we've got any DSP nerds in the forum.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got some ideas for you. 
1) if your gain staging is done properly, you’ll notice when the low end starts to interact negatively with the rest of the frequency bands. 
2) reference reference reference. Listen to songs with the kind of low-end you’re looking for and reference them diligently.
3) have someone you trust that can tell you how it’s going when you think you’re getting close. I got a road rig together for mixing, expecting that I’d get 70% there before finishing in my studio. Surprisingly I got closer to 95% just using good techniques ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
4) its like anything else, the more you do it, the better you get at it. 

I hope this helps. Andrew Scheps is on headphones now and he seems to be real happy. You might be able to find some good insight from him.

Also keep in mind I do mostly Country Music and bedroom pop, which aren’t necessarily the most bass heavy genres.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If it's really upsetting me I might deal with it early, but I prefer to live with those details as I get the drum mix together - there's (usually) going to be bus compression, maybe added fake Oceanway room, samples and their idiosyncracies - so many variables, all often getting processed on drum bus (+ potential parallels per song section).

By the time I'm done with that it usually just feels more like a general vibe than an exercise in precision - the snare ring in the left room mic might draw the ear away from the kick flam in the right (or that flam could now groove in a cool way as the comps breathe, or it slaps against a rhythm guitar part or whatever), but I can always go back and Time Adjuster (or L/R EQ with Fab or whatever) the rooms if they're really bothering me.

Same reason I don't usually address snare rings until I've got the drums working well

author: cian riordan
content: For me its all about parallel drum busses. One clean, wide open -- that preserves all the transient information, which you can exaggerate further with transient tools. One very compressed -- distressor style, to bring up the life in the room. And one distorted -- usually something like Decapitator with a low-shelf before it. I feel like in this situation, you could have your cake and eat it with what you're looking for.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
With just three tracks I’d be too analytical for that clever approach 👆🏻

I’d run versions of each track with all methods available and have them on playlists. Some methods work better for different types of material, different frequency content, different transient preservation… 

I’d do the grunt work then flip between playlists until I got everything feeling the best it could. Eg a lot of times RX sounds “smoothest” on stereo material with high end content, but soundshifter parametric in sync mode can sound garbly and subtly artefacty, but retains or even sometimes adds a vibe. 

Suck it and see.

author: Rob Domos
content:
It sounds cloudy, less solid, and like you’re losing texture. 

This largely happens because phase delay and group delay changes imposed by an eq aren’t linearly correlated to each other, so you end up getting a blurring that sounds kind of like a very short and close first reflection

author: Rob Domos
content:
To answer this, buffer size can impact windowing, and windowing can impact the ringing of an EQ and the side-lobing of an fft which would change the sound of any spectral processing. 

So yes, changing your buffer size will impact the sound of some processing. Not enough for me to have paid attention to it outside of mere book knowledge, but maybe I’ll peep it just to see what I notice. 🤔

They totally reworked the workflow.  You slap it on anything you want and it will organize sources together that are multi-mic (this doesn't work 100% well and I still group manually). author: Rollmottle
content:
the case is the same digital or analog. it's a helpful tool to keep your gain staging in check. the key is what you calibrate the meter to and where you place it. 

it seems particularly useful on making sure you're hitting known processing chain inputs in their sweet spot. put the meter before any bus processing chain and calibrate the meter to its sweet spot. now you know quickly when you're hitting (or not hitting) the spot where you know it can do the thing in the way you expect it to do the thing. the other really useful one is post bus processing. set the meter on a bus output calibrated to a target level, now you know how gain decisions within the bus are or are not getting you where you want to be. for those working in templates and mixing into known bus processing chains, it seems like it would take a lot of the guess work out of gain staging decisions. it's a very broad stroke tool, but helps me very quickly make decisions on what level something needs to be juiced up or down to. just takes a little upfront work.

If your snare frequencies are phase cancelling kick frequencies you’re either playing a very odd drum kit or you’ve fucked up on the engineering front. I’ve recorded more live drums than most, and yes while nothing is off the table for fixing a problem (if it sounds good it is good!) this still sounds like fixing a bad engineering problem with a questionable editing problem. author: JustinLeu
content: In my experience you can open up RX-Mouth de-click, RX-de-click (I have my default to multiband mode), and an instance of pro-q3 audio-suite with a HP filter around 200hz on “A” and then flip to “B” and set it to the HP filter and a low-shelf around 800-1K subtracting -8 with the output knob set to -10. I listen to the vocal without fx, but with comp/eq somewhere around what it might be in the mix. Make a new playlist then edit clicks/pops with the RX-tools and plosives with “A” setting on pro-q. The “B” setting I described will be used to clean up breaths that have annoying frequency build up or “s” sounds that maybe not be recorded the best…I’ll change those settings to make it fit what ever I need to. This does not take long to do and sometimes I will use mouth-de click on the whole audio file with a gentle setting to start.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: If you match the output level, boosts are cuts and cuts are boosts, and it becomes a question of workflow. If there's dynamic or harmonic processing downstream, then it's about pushing harder into the processing vs. pushing less hard, and that's of course a choice to make. Some EQs (e.g. API) perhaps lend themselves to additive work because the proportional Q is super wide at +-2dB and sometimes people think of subtractive EQ as a tool for more narrow resonance notching, and it's a bit unfamiliar to have -2dB with a Q of 0.5 or whatever.

author: Jonathan Jetter

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: This might not be the most helpful answer but I think you have to start by being able to hear the full spectrum in stereo. If your speakers don't reach far down into the bass, and/or if you're summing to a mono sub, how can you make decisions on stereo content in the lows vs. the low mids?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: And while we're less sensitive to directionality in a low frequency signal I do think the phase interaction between differences in L + R LF content is clearly audible, and sometimes crucially important to certain sounds. I really do find the LF Side high-pass / mono-making thing is often quite a compromise. And, both widening + narrowing via M/S will often have unintended effects on the overall image. Things that were hard panned now won't be, etc.

content:
Honestly have considered it, but I would normally just tell them what I think, if there should be changes and not charge them for a consult or something. 

Or ideally send them your way (I have actually tried sending some literally to you haha, but the few times they didn't bite on it) -- I think the way of listening as a mixer is just different to what I have been working on. @Nomograph Mastering has referred to this before I think and I find it's true.

A few times in a situation like that, a producer has sent me their entire mix bus plus the mix without it...and just bypassing half of the stuff does the trick almost immediately. The standard wild stuff going on...huge amounts of gold clip, all the new ozone bells and whistles, etc etc. Which aren't inherently bad but in my monitoring I can normally just get rid of it and use a simple EQ or something -- and I'm talking huge improvements. I think it's just down to a fresh perspective and great monitoring.

I'm not sure what to make of it honestly, I don't plan on changing how I operate, the move is always to get artists and producers to great mixers IMO whenever possible, and I love the team aspect of that, I think the art is better for it.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: Deleted User
content:
I love midrange mess. 

having good amount of midrange to poke out is the right idea. It just needs to be distributed in a way that makes sense to our ears. 

Low and high end lacking could mean that there’s actually not enough of them, but it could also mean that the midrange isn’t distributed in a way that lets the low end be pushing the speakers and be able to hear the top end *distinctively. 

In terms of midrange distribution, I found it helpful to think about “where do I want this instrument to occupy in the mids?” -> to do this, context is absolutely necessary. I’m not a mixer, but I like to produce with that in mind, and once I get to the mixing process then I listen to the whole thing and start thinking about where I want to put things. 

and then there is this new thing I’m starting to find and explore- “what instruments want to push the speakers together in xHz area?” 

sometimes boosting the same area in two different elements that hit simultaneously help tighten things up and glue things together, rather than everything moving front and back all over the place. 

I used to think everything has to be separated like a jigsaw puzzle, but I’m only starting to realize that not how audio works. these days I’m learning that some things will want to occupy the presence in the same or similar area, and that is the thing that helps the mixes feel more coherent sometimes.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.

author: iampedrorafael
content: Same situation here, I used to avoid the "reality check" at the beginning of the mix so I could move primarily by feel. But then I was consistently making macro EQ moves on the mix bus in order to match the references a bit more at the end of the mix (typical 2db presence boost, maybe some 200-300hz scoop). This was a real pain in the ass, cause naturally things change a bit at that point and it's not an effective way to handle the problem. So now I have a preset for MetricAB with 8 reference tracks ready to go that I listen for short periods of time, sometimes 5 seconds or so, just to keep my years calibrated to what "normal" feels like in a macro-level. The fact that I don't need to leave the DAW environment (changing the visuals as well) to open a streaming app with different stimulus makes it really convenient to just do the right thing and compare apples to apples. The band-isolation mode really helps me to compare how different frequency ranges are moving also

author: cian riordan
content: There will always be a phase interaction if you have two parallel processing chains on a single source. In the case of the amp, there's a physical delay in the sound coming out of the speaker and hitting the microphone. In the case of an amp sim, there's just so many variables there (if its trying to replicate that physical delay, delay compensation, etc). Best to just check that stuff with a phase switch though. I wouldn't dig too much into this HPF idea... it's really solving for a different problem.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This is good to know. The way I approached it was to build the mix with loads of headroom, then when it was all sitting roughly where it wanted to be, I’d alt+drag the input/output of Saturn to wherever it sounded good. It was usually followed by The Glue or another compressor (not always). When I first started using it I was thinking about where the harmonic stages would happen in a (Un)fairchild. I guess probably pre and post compression? There’s probably arguments to compress pre saturation, but I auditioned compression before and after Saturn and preferred it post on that occasion, so that’s how it stayed in the template.

The Pro-Q curve hedged against a tendency I had/have to mix too smiley, and all in all it seemed to make things sound more gooder so the duo lived on in my template… until it didn’t.

author: Colin Althaus
content:
I’ve found this often has to do with phase artifacts in M-S processing causing the image to sum together in odd ways (sometimes even ending up on the opposite side!)

Think of M-S processing like algebra. When converting left-right to mid-side (which is really sum-difference):

M = L + R
S = L - R

To reconstruct L and R,
L = 0.5(M + S)
R = 0.5(M - S)

So whether something appears on L or R is determined by its phase relationship on the S channel (+S or -S) relative to the M channel.

Flip the polarity of the whole S channel (+S to -S) and the whole image reverses: L becomes R, and R becomes L.

Now imagine a steep filter like a 24dB/oct HPF… here is a screenshot of the measured phase response. At the corner frequency of 100Hz we see the signal is 180 degrees out of phase.

author: chrissorem
content:
Makes sense and I agree.  Seems like everyone eventually mutes some major groups and solos to hear how things are affecting each other. I like to work with everything in to learn the arrangement and for gain structure reasons I like to start work all in and the biggest section and work backwards. Then as I’m working and I’m fighting something, I’ll start to mute all guitars, or all keys ect…
And see how things are affecting each other and decide who going to give in… and then I’ll listen to just  drums and bass for a while and then I’ll add guitars back and then I’ll Listen to drums and guitars for a bit… and deferent variations of this and I’ll get a deeper understanding of the frequency conflict and I’ll think about  how I want to approach it .

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. Trying this out.  I'm not gonna be as thorough this time, because that's a lot of variables to document with photos. So I'll give you my general observations and y'all can take me at my word.

I dropped the input signal to -20dB and then played around with boosting at 100Hz (where my test tone is) to see if the harmonics were different for different EQ band types. I tried a *bell*, a *low shelf*, and a *tilt shelf* to boost.

I was able to boost it +16dB in both *subtle* and *warm* mode before I got any of that harmonic breakup that we started to see in my previous tests as we got approached -0.03 dB. It appears that distortion on *subtle* mode (once again) doesn't kick in at all until the output signal gets within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. The *amount* I boosted did not matter. The distortion only came when the signal crept close to 0 on the output meter.

All three band types appeared to behave the same when it came to harmonic bloom.
### tl;dr:
I did not detect any difference in behavior with different EQ band types. So they appear to behave the same. It's looking like the breakup doesn't kick in until the output level of the signal is within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. *Then* they start to break up.

The only exception is the 1st order harmonic at -22dB that appears as soon as you enable *warm* mode. That's always present, no matter how hard you're driving it.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I wouldn’t agree that it’s mere fluctuation or that it means basically nothing. 

A vast majority of sounds specifically go from sharper to flatter over time (energy dissipation reduces the frequency of a vibration) and this is VERY responsible for a sense of impact and the  3-dimensionality of a sound. 

When producing synthetic sounds, shaping the pitch envelope is IMO one of the fastest, most impactful, and most overlooked ways to get them from “meh” to totally fucking sick. Like I’d go as far as to say it’s one of the main separators between intermediate and excellent sound design in electronic music
