author: David Fuller
content: well think about it right - a multiband compressor is a frequency limited compressor, and it affects dynamics of a given frequency range. A dynamic EQ is a level affected EQ, and it affects EQ of a given dynamic range. They both basically end up doing the same thing - dynamic control of frequency - but go about it differently.

author: peterlabberton
content: @hendrick I think loudness certainly has a bit to do with it, but I think there are a few other things at play as well. I could have my recording history wrong here, but my impression is that it wasn’t until the GML 8200 EQs came around that we really had super narrow surgical EQs. If you’re gonna go for the modern sound but still record acoustic instruments, tweezing out nasty resonances with EQ plays a big role—no way they could do that with 1073s. Also I think moving to (good sounding) digital made a big difference: you could get loads more bottom end, which was really taken advantage of in the best way with hip hop setting the bar for what we expect in that regard.

content:
0.1 is a percentage as far as i know. The actual amount of saturation deoends both on that the mix knob and the og sources inherent Harmonics that get excited. 

That same amount ona heavy bass won't saturate the same as ona soft flute for example (also depends on the freq  range)

That said I know a lot of mixers that swear by the warm mode on the exciter for even Harmonics And they are very subtle w it.

The eq idk. I'll never really used it but similarly I know a lot of mixers that swear by it. If there's really that much of a difference it's either 1. That's how it is on the eq that it's trying to emulate- it's a vintage style eq, I don't think it's meant to be linear in any way. 

2. There's something wrong w the plug and I'd suggest hitting up support about it.

author: Maxim
content:
I mean without music in context there's not a ton to say. And even if you managed to get the room out of the vocal (which with plugins like RX 8/9, C-VOX, SPL De-Verb, etc. is still not great) I doubt you'd be left with much that's "nice" to work with. 

But nevertheless, after doing some processing with the usual tools (best mentioned above - look into the new Dialog Isolate from RX 9) my intuition would be to eq the lower mids/lows first in the context of the music to get rid of the room "mud". 

Then maybe (lightly) slap some Soothe or Gullfoss on there to see what that does. Then once you've possibly got something to work with, go through the usual steps you might process a vocal with  (more additive/tone-shaping tools to get a sound).

Thing is, if you don't have all these plugins already it would be much cheaper to just record a better vocal. (I think you can demo them all though?) Maybe even consider renting a studio for a day (if the artist has the budget).

content: For acoustic piano, its always 2 or 3 parallel chains of heavy compression and/or filtered distortion to even out resonances and get the chords to really speak...  tucked with the unprocessed piano always doing the speaking in the high end. (the heavy processed signals tucked in so they're not audible, just filling in the blanks)

author: rse
content:
This is really valuable! Thanks a lot. To go into some of your questions; I'm using Adam a7's (not the newer a7x's, although I tested them and they're wasn't as much of a difference as I had expected in my room). My room has been treated with diy panels, 14cm thick Rockwool and it sounds decent for a home recording studio. the dimensions aren't great and low lend monitoring isn't top of the charts but it's workable. Any peaks and valleys i did have have been sorted out further as much as possible with sonarworks which has really outdone my expectations. I also use Beyerdynamics dt770 pro's. 
Usually a lot of time does actually go into clip gaining, cleaning up and taking harshness out of vocals. I often take as much time just manually leveling a vocal, taking out esses etc as I do mixing. Fresh air and dopamine have indeed been big helpers and have been big steps towards that sizzle. Also the waves exciter in parallel has been working okay.
I never seem to be able to get a multiband compressor to work well. Either I'm overdoing some of the setting or something because often i feel like it attenuates too much and other times to little in the places I want it to. I've noticed that a little boost in the low mids on pro-q3 that then also attenuates dynamically can work. 
Could you go into a bit more detail on what you mean with phase bringing a vocal more forward?
I've also noticed that a lot of the sound I'm looking for comes from a certain sort of rolling kind of sound that might be coming from the rappers throat? I'm not sure at all about this but it seems like it's almost vocal fry but in a very natural way that is inherent to the singers/rappers voice. Idk if this is a rapping technique thing or if this is more accentuated in the mixing process, but it sounds really nice.
Definitely a big thankyou for all the tips!

author: rse
content: Been using a lot of dynamic cuts on pro-q3 tho but it serves not quite te same function for me as a full spectrum multiband compressor, it's a little more of a corrective thing and not a "toneshaper" i guess

author: bobby k
content: man I need some advice here. got paid up front to mix an album and it's taken over a year to complete, just feeling not worth it anymore. The issue we keep running in to is really terrible engineering and production caked into the vocals by this very large/random span of producer (14 total songs), then the artist says that every vocal feels over compressed (I can assure you that none of it is coming from me). I've told her time and time again that perhaps these notes would have been more effective during production or recording, but it still feels like it's my fault. (also, fun tidbit: her verbage is "the eq on the vocal feels too compressed"). she references the mixes on very old Apple earbuds and has the most ludacris notes about the bass n stuff. I'm mixing on PMC IB1s and Airpods, FWIW. just feels like this endless uphill battle where I'm worried I'm running thin on patience.

author: bobby k
content: Yup, I've talked on the phone with a couple friends and it feels very clear I need to walk away. I think the way you explained it though was super helpful; that the boundaries were exceeded and I'm unable to continue. We actually do have a contract, but it quite literally has 1 sentence detailing the mixing responsibilities...the rest is about points on a production I finished for her over a year ago. SO WEIRD that this contract represents both things?? Anyways, the consensus I've come to is to pull out the calculator and figure out what my "kill fee" is for the amount of work I've done already, then subtract that from the flat fee I got upfront for mixing (7 out of 13 mixes are approved). The valuable lesson I've learned here is: A. the artist has to like their own music (I just don't think this is true with her...lots of insecurities). B. the artist has to like what I do (again I don't know where I'm going wrong, but she seems to think mixing can save a song). C. I have to like the music (I don't, and I haven't from the beginning). I think all 3 of these points are valuable before committing to a full album.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not totally sure. I don’t think metering is going to help you. I’d avoid a mix by numbers approach. Maybe your monitoring needs some attention. A bad room can really make it painfully hard to make confident decisions that translate in the moment or even later in mixing.

Templates to me speed up your workflow not necessarily help you make better decisions if that makes sense. It’s like, setting up several busses you ALWAYS make, so instead of doing 100 keystrokes and commands to get your busses and FX built, two clicks and they’re there for you.

I don’t know what genre / style / level you’re working at, but I’d say just keep working at it. I love recording music because you can ALWAYS do it again. Time is the only thing you have to lose. With enough time, anything is possible. 

That said, looking at a frequency analyzer of a whole mix you like isn’t a horrible thing to do. Maybe you’ll see your mix is way too dark, or way too thin simply.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Such a great question. 2 things that really help me with this- top end and dryness. The ear perceives brighter elements as closer, so choosing what’s bright in your mix really effects what feels closer to you. EQ IS VOLUME. secondly, the more dry the more forward it feels.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There’s no wrong way to eat a Reese’s. It all depends on what you’re trying to accomplish! But think of using PP auxes like a Mix Knob. 

As far as vocals, there’s all kinds of ways to do this. I often take a tuned vocal, set the output to a bus that feeds 2 separate auxes with dif types of compression, and then bus both of those back into a single Aux which I treat as if it were the originally recorded vocal track. 

I use spitty 1176 type comp on one and a smoother VariMu type comp on the other, then eq any unwanted resonances and de ess before sending them to the final Aux.

i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

author: ehutton21
content:
agree with multiband for problematic performances and/or songs where the artist is craving a super compressed aesthetic (some of the electronic/industrial influenced pop/hip-hop type stuff). i’ve seen success with three bands for hyper compressed vox—one for low information (100Hz and below), then one from there to 1k, and then one more for everything above 1k. that’s the default in MC404 

MBs are kinda hard to rationalize for me on most anything else outside of sound design, which is part of what i think people (at least some of my people) want. MBs are great for really handling what you don’t want in a sound or over pronouncing something for effect though, IMO. if i need to really kill a region of like low mids, i can obliterate anything with pro-mb. dynamic eq way more precise but also better gentle for gentle strokes.

author: rse
content: Something has been bugging me a little since I've found a lot of contradictory information on the topic. I will try to describe what I think will happen, correct me if I'm wrong. When I send a signal out to a parallel compression track, compress it and then EQ, that EQ will be in parallel to the main signal. Since EQ causes fase shift this could create problems (I think?). I've noticed from doing some test and research that bell and shelve curves wouldn't really have any weird behaviors in this case, only that bell curves would have a slightly different Q and shelves would be shifted up or down in frequency ever so slightly. Filters seem to be where the real problems are, since they introduce a full 180° phase rotation in the frequency area around the cutoff (i forgot where exactly) kinda similar to what an all pass filter would introduce but with added shift below or above the cutoff frequency depended on HP or LP. So bell and shelve curves should behave very predictably, but filters would behave in more unexpected ways. It's all kinda messy in my head because of different information sources. The internet is an amazing place but it's really hard to get good, clear and correct information sometimes.

author: Will Melones
content:
I have been avoiding parallel EQ ever since this same thing came to my attention, but Dan Worrall’s video on it is pretty compelling. 

https://youtu.be/RL4KDVFlkUg

author: Will Melones
content: Yeah, just like Matt is saying I think the only thing to focus on is how good it sounds. A boost at the nastiest frequency is going to be far more detrimental than the phase cancellation from that boost in parallel, so there’s no way you can do it without trusting your ears anyway. Sometimes the selective frequency cancellation IS part of the tone. Tchad Blake will shift two tracks out of phase from one another as a kind of tone knob, and he seems to have done pretty well!

author: ehutton21
content: This used to be a weak spot of mine and to be fair I think everyone constantly fights these kind of battles. I recommend putting your mix in mono from the jump for a while and heavily rely on filtered listening (so NS10s or mixcubes) as you gain stage and make yourself get the sound good in mono. It feels like 101 level stuff at times but if you’re not forcing things to mono and isolating ranges, you’re not forcing yourself to make the real big EQ strokes. That’s why I love my cubes—I gotta be bold and decisive to be big on cubes.

author: ALXCPH
content: i remember Jon at one point talking about shifting a bass, an octave down in a mix he was doing, and suddenly there was room for the bass and what ever element it was competing with, and the clients loved it. So if you are really struggling with a mix, it can be very helpful to try and shift things up and down an octave, while also having good communication with the producer, explaining why you are doing such moves.

author: ehutton21
content:
I’ve got sent a snare drum with mono compatibility issues, but not  in terms of its recorded nature (it was a sample, not mic’d off a drum kit). It’s clear that in the low mids, some kind of synthesis is going on with a distortion/feedback effect to add this ‘diving’ sine wave effect right before the transient of the snare connects (so it’s like if you had an open hat hitting right before the snare).
 
In mono, that low mid resonance effect disappears though, but the actual transient sound remains in tact.

I swear by the Octoverb preset in valhalla delay—put it on an aux and send the lead vocals out to it, (autotune it a bit to be really clean) and level it to taste but it’ll add a really satisfying, violin-synth like shimmer during a chorus. author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I’ve been dealing with this today, but the vocalist has extremely bright/sibilant/harsh strident capsule resonances popping up in different places like 5k, 7k, 10k etc. Sometimes the tightest q cuts worked at the pin-like resonances piercing through, other times a literal notch provided the smoothest results. I was trying Soothe for anything above 5kHz and sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn’t.

Different sections and phrases had different capsule resonances, like the tube in the mic was fluctuating based on temperature/humidity causing all sorts of nasties. I ended up using Audiosuite on the odd phrase here or there and manually cutting the resonances with a tight Q or notch (in addition to what was on the channel).

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m starting to believe I’m not as good at treating vocals as I thought I was. Usually the stuff I get to mix is recorded in a bedroom or worse on a cheap condenser mic, and I’ll do what I can to polish the turd, but at some point it’s as good as it can get.

But then I listen to some of the previous releases some of these artists have, and I wonder if the folks who mixed those songs had to work with the same quality raw material. The stuff sounds pro in the end (sometimes).

It seems like this is more and more the way things will be for good. It’s rare that someone is singing into a decent mic and pre in a treated room (studio!?) or that they bother with mic technique.

Does anyone have tips or resources related to *really* digging into the repair of things like wonky room resonances, harsh-ass mics, inconsistent distance, and sometimes no talent? It seems like the folks working in that next level up can wave a magic wand and turn an NT1A into a 251 without harshness or dullness.

I always thought vocal recording was pretty clear cut. I guess I spoiled myself because all of the stuff I mixed early on I had recorded myself, and my only real ‘vocal’ mic was an RE20.

author: ehutton21
content:
Tools like soothe2, pro-q3, spectral shaper, are absolutely essential when I work with poor recordings and they’re frequently used in my chain. 

With soothe, i use it because I hate resonance hunting in pro-q, so I’ll set up a soothe2 band with the mix at 50% which is limiting GR to like 6.0db with a selectivity of above 5.0 and a sharpness ~5-6. Listen, solo delta, hunt till satisfied, repeat. Spectral shaper at 0.0, attack and release close around 10-15 in light and im knocking a 1-2dbs off in the low mids usually (which doesn’t require a harsh threshold), and maybe another spectral shaper that’s broadly working from 2k-6k (esp on the NT1A) is essential. MC404 is great for proximity effect, i set the bands to rel. 2 mode and filter 100Hz and below, compress 100-1k for about 2-3 dbs of GR, and hit 1k onwards with 1-2db.

author: ehutton21
content: Yeah, it depends. I like room ambience match in RX if I need it and I mean we all know the slog of clip gain, pro-q, clipper, repeat. When it comes to taking something like wild resonances though I like tools that don’t make me overthink, and with soothe and multiband I gain tonal control I can’t gain otherwise

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste. 

Bottom without woof and top without sibilance are what make your vocals sound pro, and there’s no one way to skin that cat properly.

author: BillyC
content: I do kinda fuck with this as a default approach, but not because it's "EQing your speakers". Managing contrast well in a mix generally makes for a more immersive feel (even in stereo), and you do lose a bit of contrast between elements with every bit of processing that's on the entire mix bus. So I tend to have better results addressing EQ inside the mix first rather than beginning the mix with some preset curve that is likely to work against me.

author: BatMeckley
content:
So I had to mix this live thing for an artist, and her mic technique left much to be desired with resonances… multi band won’t cut it… so…

Open up fab filter, engage the visual RTA, grab a fairly sharp bell, and set the gain and the frequency to write on your automation. Now, literally go through the track, and chase the specific resonances like you were playing and old 80’s arcade game. You should be able to see them pop up in the rta, then just counteract them with the least amount of gain reduction that you can get away with. Usually takes me 3 passes total to really dial it in. 10-15 minutes later, alll good!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've been playing around with the new *Stabilizer* module in *Ozone 10* (which is similar to Gullfoss), and I dig it. It's not bad. I've been using it on my 2-buss for my last two mixes.

*However,* you have to be careful with it. If you solo an instrument/group/etc, it will adapt its curve to *those* instruments, meaning it's now optimizing it's EQ for the subgroup, which can misrepresent the moves that you need to be making.

I'm also realizing that printing stems is going to be problematic with that on a stereo buss because the *Stabilizer* is going to adapt it's curve to each solo'd channel (facepalm).

On second-thought, this might be best reserved as a mastering tool only, or else only lean on it *very* lightly and print your stems with it off.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Frequency Masking is huge, but we just aren’t sensitive to phase shift in a single sound source

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: A really important thing to understand re phase is that phase and magnitude are two sides of the same coin. If the frequency response of a source is modified, it’s phase will be too, and given a minimum phase problem we actually WANT the EQs phase shift as part of the correction

So I got into this when tryn figured out how to get depth in a mix. (This was after gainstaging, top and bottom, wideness, but before loudness and also im still learning all of it.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried out the demo and was kind of put off by how severe the EQ sculpting is. It’s voiced very very bright. Maybe that’s the sauce in pop mixes, but it felt extreme to me. I found myself having to turn up the low shelf a lot to account for how bright it is.

The level rider seemed pretty good. And the compressor gets pumpy quick, but it was alright in small doses.

The doubler felt great and the two verb options sounded excellent, but I could see them being limited because they only have a dry/wet control.

Overall I like that it can act as an instant-vibe plugin for when you want to move quickly through a session. It’s got zero latency, which is great and seemed very light on CPU. But it’s not a fit for every style. Seemingly just for big pop stuff.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The decision whether to use a hard clipper before Pro L2 is super easy. If there are big poky transients like snares then clipping works really well to keep that energy but control it (really we spread it across the frequency spectrum). If the mix is more dense and steady state then clippers don’t work

author: Zack Hames

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Are they apparent when all of the mics are in? Sometimes that stuff is better addressed on the bus. Have you engaged drum bus processing (if any)? Sometimes thickening and/or darkening the drum bus (Pultec 100Hz, Studer Tape, whatever) renders this upper mid/high stuff less abrasive.

Sometimes addressing too much of this stuff sucks life out of drums. I leave most mad snare ringing in as I work on the drums - it often winds up being cool stuff to add to the pumping energy with heavier parallel compressors, or distortions.

Is it apparent/interfering with the mix as a whole?

1. Things to Ques Yourself before Setting up a Room Reverb.

author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: Deleted User

For that reason the challenge I’ve been having working with synths is to get the kind of bigness acoustic instruments have. Which is one of the few different reasons why I think we layer synths with different envelopes and frequency allotment to give focus and presence in the right areas at the same time.

author: Deleted User
content:
The bigness of synth and samples probably is at the consistency of it, but I always felt like acoustic instruments takes less work to sound big and immersive because they already are. Acoustic instruments may take compression, editing and some aggressive band limiting and EQ moves to make it work in the mix, but those moves tend not to work for synths in my experience. So other things need to be done like parameter automation and layering

Bass guitar is probably not gonna have as consistent in your face subs like 808s, but the life of it always felt more massive than 808 to me. 

Soft synths sound huge on their own because they have very consistent presence but when you turn the faders down for balance, it gets smaller again. So  as many mentioned it takes making it smaller to make it bigger again. I guess this also applies to distorted guitars

author: Deleted User
content:
I find that delays can take some aggresive EQs depending on the style. Give a wild boost on area where I want the delay to cut through and turn the overall delay down - and then compress it a little bit to duck it. 

At least for reverb- I find it’s not always necessarily to have a dry signal keying the compressor to duck the reverb.  Sometimes just a compressor directly on the channel will do something similar and less dramatic than ducking if that’s what is needed for the song, 

Also I find faders very helpful in automating effects. Because I don’t always want them to duck in the same shape or ducking is something I’d do to change the nature of the tail and will still need some additional shaping to give specialness to different moments.

For vocals I like copying the audio track and make separate fx tracks because I only want it on certain words. Even for overall effect, I use a separate track so I can take out certain words from reverb or clip gain them. Or even fade in words when I don’t want the early part of reverb poking out too much in certain parts.

I have a TC clarity…and I almost never look at it. I can definitely see it being more helpful in a mixing context ala @cian riordan …but I just find that I never end up caring about the level and only care about the feel (which is of course tied to the level/density)

Of course I always listen at the same volume every day, and I think @Nomograph Mastering mentioned before he does the same…as such it’s easy to tell when something is getting too hot or isn’t loud enough yet!

Have never once really looked at it during a master, only at the end sorta as a “let’s see where it ended up”…

I don’t say this to discourage you from using one, only that IMO it’s not something that is necessarily needed at all

author: stefanmacc
content:
There are others here that can probably answer this better. But IMO you don’t want to rely on the limiter as a way to achieve loudness or excitement in a mix because you’ll likely end up with a crushed muddy mess… The limiter is not very good at those jobs.

Also LUFS is perceived loudness meaning EQ plays a huge role in that.. Distortion / Saturation plays a big role..  

So limiting should be one slice of the pie when it comes to achieving level… the rest should be done within the mix with the correct EQ moves . Correct distortion and some compression (not too much)

author: CK
content: just gonna throw this out there...Try the God Particle as your only mix bus plugin.  Use all the sweet spot targets, and forget about how much it is limiting.  Focus on getting the EQ targets dialed in with your mix, and the input target not clipping..  This taught me SO much about loudness.  My mixes consistently hit -9rms and -9 lufs when I get them dialed with EQ, and I no longer get the "smushed" feeling I used to get when trying to get loud. The mix actually breathes and is loud AF. Then when I get the eq targets dialed in, I see where I am hitting large amounts of peaks over 3-4db on the limiter, and then I address those peaks at the source in different ways. The God Particle I truly think can be a teaching tool, as well as a great sounding mix bus tool. I am now using it less and experimenting with my own chains. But seriously, this may help you as it helped me. The GP does not suck and I will always have it in the bag as sometimes it is just the right sauce.

author: esquinalee
content:
I like to put an ssl-g comp style channel strip plug with eq, gating, and compression specific to the kick in and kick out, very subtly use standard clip to taste on each of the two (or not/or later on the bus) and bus those both to a kick bus where I’ll do some additive eq and a tiny bit of compression and then bounce it down to just one kick track once the balance between them is set and the character of the sound is together.
I find it’s nice to have the kicks all one aux and it’s easier to control the sound as one without dealing with different mic sources and sometimes it’s nice to not even route the kick bus to the drum bus, depending on the song and desired effect.

author: popthetrunk
content:
The manual is pretty straightforward and in the getting started section it gives a good overview. 

But basically it’s trying to auto eq for clarity on any audio input, and they claim it’s artifact free. Tame reduces things it counts as dominant and recover adds things it thinks are being masked. Bias and brighten modulate how those things happen, but only affect the audio if tame and recover have a non zero value. The red lines on the edge of the freq display are range limiters that can be dragged to limit the processing to above the first and below the second(like a band pass) or dragged over each other to limit processing to just the high or low freq ranges.

In your screen shot you have 80% recover with a lot of heavy lifting below 200 and above 2k, that’s because there isn’t a ton of audio info there so gullfoss is trying to bring out whatever is there, if you range limit to where the audio is, or where you want to effect the sound gullfoss will on work on that freq range and not add a bunch of 26hz and 20k to a synth that is all midrange

author: peterlabberton
content: Yeah, the way I've seen it (and am dragging my feet to start doing on scores) is each group has its own aux, and that aux has (say) a compressor and an EQ on it. Each aux has the identical comp and EQ, and all are grouped. So then you can treat it *like* a more traditional 2bus, but then hit commit to last insert when you're done, and that's it. All these auxes just go through one limiter on the actual master. Of course, you don't get the effect of the proper sidechain on compression this way, but it seems like a decent compromise.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I think it’s basically frequency dependent phase rotation. Here’s their blurb:

“Auto-Align 2's Spectral Phase Optimization feature corrects phase shifts that can occur within specific frequency ranges, resulting in a more coherent and richer-sounding audio signal. When using filters during recording, different frequency bands can experience varying phase shifts, leading to a distorted and unclear sound. Spectral Phase Optimization automatically detects and corrects these phase shifts, ensuring that your audio is perfectly aligned and sounding its best.”

author: Deleted User
content: My guess is it isolates a frequency band and calculates what would give the best phase correlation. Takes the number of samples it needs to be nudged for best coherence in that frequency band and moves the whole thing by that much

author: JustinLeu
content:
I think this is important to realize WHY this is working. The polarity flip is making the drums (as a whole) sum the waveforms in a more pleasing and additive way. 
The way I theorize this is happening is because while all of the drum mics relative phase relationships remain the same, the frequencies that the drums produces slightly vary during a performance. These are NOT one shot samples going through the microphones. The 4 on the floor makes it much more complex because BOTH the snare and the kick are producing different tones (with variances) at the same time…The frequencies that are additive (in-phase) are relative to all of the drum mics positioning/distance from the source, BUT different frequencies will add/subtract in magnitude…that is what we are quickly checking with polarity. If you change the tuning on a snare drum for instance, it can start to become less “in phase” with the overheads because the fundamental frequency has changed and may not be complimentary between the OH/SN mics anymore at the same distance.

author: lystell
content:
On the topic of EQ
I'm doing some projects now that are live drums driven so to speak. I'm trying to up my game both when it comes to recording and mixing. 
My instinct when it comes to EQ is to subtract. In a way, it feels logical to me. Let's say I don't like the sound on a snare around 400hZ. Then my brain goes - let's remove that. 
I've been digging deeper lately into the API style of EQ and it occurred to me that when going through the preset list -  most of the presets were doing additive stuff. I find this very interesting and when it comes to "surgical sounddesign",  a new workflow for me. Like - I don't like the low mid on this snare. Let's boost the top instead. 
It feels somewhat backward but I can see some good things coming of it. 
How's your workflow?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A producer buddy of mine asked me yesterday how often I listen in mono while mixing. I said “When I find myself using too many stereo imagers to make things fit, sometimes I’ll check to see what kind of fuckery I’m causing. But honestly who listens in mono anymore?”

He reminded me a lot of small Bluetooth speakers are in mono, so I decided this morning to take a fresh look at a tune I’m producing/mixing, starting in mono. 

The leveling choices totally broke down when I switched to stereo, but I think the mix is much better and it happened faster cause I was forced to look at the eq in relation to the center elements, so even when I spread them back out there was more room for the vocal kik snare bass to speak. 

Y’all ever start a mix in mono? Or work with mono as a tool for extended periods?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Over here in the mix, I do a fair amount of widening on certain single elements, synth pads + atmosphere tracks, + backing vocal stacks. Usually just straight M/S gain adjustments. And I'll sometimes narrow certain drum overheads or room mics. And I'll sometimes have a bit of M/S EQ on the mix bus (especially if it was on the producer's rough mix).

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: JustinLeu
content:
Everything @Edward Rivera mentioned. It is a very helpful tool, but I think it can be abused and yield a terrible result even if the waveform looks "nice and even" haha.... For instance, you are seeing a waveform that is made of the entire frequency spectrum and the amplitude will be different depending on the sound/frequency makeup of each word. When you just "make it look even" and play it back, many times it sounds worse than before. Full-band and multi-band compression+saturation can sound much more natural, and is wayyyy less time consuming. You are able to get a result very quickly and remain objective. 

Clipgain is very useful...just something to be aware of!

author: Rob Domos
content:
Seeing a few people tagging me asking for more deets. I’m on holiday with fam now so a little write up will need to suffice. 

Jack’s video covered a good chunk of what I’m doing. Attenuating a few frequency hotspots and clicks is more than half of it. Unlike Jack, I use mouth declick far more than spectral repair or declick. 

There’s other things I’m doing as well but they vary from song to song. I’ll manually smooth out plosives, mic stand bumps, clothing rustles etc. I’ve even gone through and reduced the aliasing in a processed vocal (which takes fucking forever to lasso tool). 

One thing I’ve never seen anyone mention before is fades in RX. It’s a little hard to explain so I’d have to make a video for this, but I do frequency dependent fading. If you think about it, almost all sounds decay with the high end decaying faster than the low end, so when I’m fading noise floor I do the same and the result is more natural and invisible.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Also remeber that FFT length (bands) relates to sample rate. 128 for 48 kHz is equal to 256 for 96 kHz if you want the same time/frequency resolution

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But very helpful for other common anomalies too

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Great, we’ve all kind of known that. Back to FFT, which works in a LINEAR  way. If we run a 16 “band” FFT on a 48 kHz signal it will divide the audio spectrum (0 Hz to 24 kHz) into 16 evenly spaced bins or bands. Each bin is 1500 Hz wide. Think about that for a second. That means we have a a single bin that contains everything from 16500 to 18000 Hz, a very “narrow” slice as it pertains to musical interest. On the flip side we are left with only a single bin that represents everything from 0 Hz to 1500 Hz, a huge chunk of the music. If the whole point was to slice up this signal so we could do something interesting to it then that is often not the resolution we hoped for. 

I see the hands going up!! “Let’s just increase the number of bands to get more frequency resolution”. And herein lies one of the confounding things about FFT. We are caught in a frequency domain/time domain tradeoff. The finer the bands or slices the more things blur in the time domain when we reconstitute via the iFFT (of the bands we have processed any or all bands). If no processing then you can run any length FFT and then the iFFT and perfectly reconstruct the original signal. (This is what you’ll often see 16 to 48k FFT on signal meters).

So some practical examples to help you guys get a handle on this. Open a file in RX and get the spectral repair module in attenuate mode set to a strength of 1. Set bands to the lowest possible (128?), figure out how wide your bins are. Now try to do a detailed edit in the low end, you’ll notice that you don’t have much “resolution”, but up high say above 10k it’s razor sharp. Now bump up your bands to the max 4096. Do the same LF edit and you’ll suddenly have nice narrow frequency slices but you’ll see things getting very blurry in the time domain, tight kicks become smeary whooshes

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. Less and less these days. A full mix might only have 2-3 effects sends on it. I've moved to a workflow where each channel (or group of instruments) get their own "send effects" right on the channel.

This is partly because a lot of the tools I use now include EQ and dynamics processing that allow me to sculpt within the plugin, and it's is partly because Ableton's rack tools enable me to easily set up parallel processing for effects within the channel without the need to mult-out or send the instrument to separate channels. author: chrissorem
content: No worries.  Yes frequency masking or congestion is like two people talking at once at the same volume. Your Brain interrupts this as blurry and confusing. That’s fine if you want it to sound unison. But if the goal is clarity and separation then you need to find a place where one isn’t in the way of the other. I like to think of this as guiding the ear. Example: I’d like to hear the vocal close but I want to feel longer.  In this instance I’d use pre delay in the reverb and darken the reverb  to achieve this.

author: spectrummasters
content: ...im aiming for the dynamic range between the moments where the kick and bass hit seperately...to when they hit together....to be my low end dynamic overall (if that makes sense)....so i dont want to flatten that range there....and instead prefer to compress the kick and bass seprately on their own buses . Im using parrallels of my kick and bass to get my loudness and harmonics, pre Low End Bus . If id want more control id consider a hz-dependent side chain on the bass from the kick, but dont like how that f's with the attack of the bass. Trying to do less processing at all stages......and get there with better balancing ..... So...a tiny bit of  comp on the kick and bass buses (0.5 db slow attack, fast release...usually neutron comp) and only an eq and standard clip on the kick bass bus to only catch random peaks and not jam the final  limiter . i like a littler expansion also , playing around with the pro G expnasion mode is fun

author: Rob Domos
content:
1) I know exactly what you’re talking about. For me, a couple things have helped 

- try shelving the lows rather than use a HPF. I’ll even cascade a couple of shelves sometimes if I have to go crazy, or shelve 150 and HP 50. You can get similar amounts of attenuation and the shape of the phase rotation feels a little less fake.

- how much of this are you doing in solo? Often the phase fuckery bothers me in solo and doesn’t as soon as the 808 is bumping. 

- sometimes I just let the lowend be loose and say “fuck it. My mix, my aesthetic choice”. Seems like not many agree but I like lowend in my vocal.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Re: 1 - i find a decent fast compressor can even this out without even hi-passing. The fact that the energy is in that are will trigger the compressor and push it down -even the dynamics and the frequency range. UAD 1176 does this for me but i’m sure any of the other clones would do the trick. So I often start with that and then EQ after. Doesn’t always work but i’ve had a bit of success with that approach recently.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Clippers can be great on busses. Great on drums etc… I find Standard Clip to be super intuitive to use and you can visualize what is happening. (Probably helpful if you are trying to gain understanding)

On the mixbus it can be helpful before the limiter but most of the time I would introduce it towards the end of a mix if at all. I would try hard clipping or a more gentle knee and see if between that and a limiter I can get something better than limiting alone.

Keep in mind that any saturation plugin (tube/tape) on the mix bus is “clipping” (soft clipping) and I find that gain staging in to that type of processing is more friendly to mix in to rather than hard clipping.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@cian riordan If there are multi-tracked drums, I'll usually do my whole process of leveling, phase checking, quick EQ voicing on those first. Then go to the loudest part of the song and quickly audition maximizer vs. vintage lim vs. Pro-L2 to get things to hit ~-9 LUFS on my Clarity M loudness radar (really great visualization for quickly doing this). Then I just get to work on the mix. Things often end up getting louder throughout the process and I'm OK with that. I'm often going back and checking to make sure things aren't overcooked. I should change my language from 'set it and forget it' to 'set it, forget it, but go back and check every now end then'.”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I can't speak to the mixing aspect of it (I only master), but a few points I've found helpful:

I use notion, but any type of board thing would be fine -- colums for "confirmed/files here", "sent", "revisions needed", "alts needed" (after approval usually), etc etc have helped. Trello or Notion allows you to keep any notes in the actual card itself, which may be helpful with management or more people involved. I have a separate Notion board for potential projects until files are in, then they go in the "actual" project tracker.

For the multiple messaging fronts...I use texts.com. All messaging apps in one place (email included, though you can't reply there) in an iMessage like format. I know @Nomograph Mastering has concerns about anything like that in regards to security, but I've looked into it and it seems very secure for where I'm at (anything sensitive I am password protecting files, etc as well).

As far as revisions, I'm sure most of us try to keep it as timely as possible. Normally I try to do it ASAP, same day or next day latest. And as you know, when you are busy revisions are a very real thing to consider, especially if your number of projects is high. I do revisions very fast -- take the note, implement it, send. For instance just yesterday was sailing along...BOOM. Revision from something two months ago. If you're working on hundred+ projects a month that's just the norm, even if 90 percent get approved first pass. Gotta be able to roll on that very fast, people really appreciate it (I know you know this, saying for others here too). Which requires good tracking, session management, etc etc.

The real trick is handing the very difficult revision processes where people go down rabbit holes, doing whatever is required for the result there but not letting it destroy the schedule. It can be tough.

All that said, I definitely have pain points I'm working on (being slow invoicing as one, sometimes there just aren't enough hours in the day)

author: shaunobi
content:
I use it and love it.

Near then end of a mix, I'll check it (in fine-grained mode, usually on the "bass heavy" curve). If I'm already sitting in the curve, I just leave it alone. If I'm a little out here and there (usually in the upper mids / highs for me) I'll put an eq (usually Weiss EQ MP or Pro Q3 - something that's not going to add "analog" saturation) right before it and make the changes it's suggesting, watching it to see if I got it close.

I think flip the EQ off and on to see if I like it more or less. Maybe half the time I DO like it more, though I often "back it off" a little, such that I'm like 50% or 70% of the way to what it's saying would be a "normal" mix.

The other ~half of the time I'm like "naw, don't like that" and disable the EQ.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: It's different to the extent that it's no longer frequency-dependent. With a single mono sound panned somewhere, if the S is quieter than the M, raising the side = panning harder. Once the S is louder than the M, you're putting antiphase content into the opposing channel.

I’ve also been loving the unfairchild plugin and it’s great on the mixbus imo. Recently have been using it for back-bus compression, a technique I heard Andrew Scheps talk about which is basically a copy of the mixbus minus drums. Mix bus stays uncompressed or less compressed. Back bus gets compressed more aggressively than I would do a mix bus. Blend that under the mix bus to taste. Really good for locking all the instrumentation together around vocals without dynamics getting pulled around by the drums. I think Andrew uses some kind of 1176 but the idea works with all kinds of compressors.

Mix bus and backbus both feed into a 2-bus where more processing may happen. Something like Pultec EQP1q, tape emultion, Pro L2? But I like to change things up!

author: bobby k
content: Some badass feedback has already been given but something I have to remind myself of every day is to focus mostly on the drum buss and mic levels/polarity. if a frequency is killing you in one mic, it’s probably in most of the others. Try EQing the buss and avoid over processing individual mics. Also, a de-esser might make a better tool than soothe for what you’re dealing with! Last thing, I’d suggest finding the mic with the best tone and building around that. sometimes people mix just the close mics and let the bleed create that glue. If you’re really up to it, you could drop the stems in a Dropbox and DM myself (or anyone else interested) to get a better idea of how “bad” it is and give more direct feedback.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Depth in a mix is fairly simple, if you can hear it. You have a few basic tools and a few more complex ones, but overall it looks like this. 

Brighter+louder=closer
Darker+quieter=further

This is also true for bottom end *mostly.*

Panning also pushes things out of the center and allows you to play with a lot more area in which to push things back. 

If you don’t have the luxury of panning, as with a snare drum, then you have volume & eq as your main tools. 

Then you have reverb. Shorter predelay, fewer short reflections & louder tails. Choosing a larger algo like a hall, etc.

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This doesn’t answer your question, but maybe it’ll help prevent this issue in the future:

I don’t think focusing on one element for a long time is ultimately helpful for the process. 

Vocals need a LOT of processing usually, so I find doing one element of that at a time, rather than all of them in one fell swoop, to be helpful. 

I like to start with an autotune, basic eq & comp & some simple ambience to out the vocal inside the song. 

Fix what’s really sticking out and then move on to other elements. 

Go back and get the esses & breaths in order 

Move back to other shit 

Come back and melodyne for real, focus on the areas that have been bugging but also tightening up timing as much as possible. 

The back to other shit. Then back for delay & ambience throws (usually toward the end of the process)

author: Rob Domos
content:
@Nomograph Mastering 

There’s so many layers to this conversation. 

One layer is: *are methods of reframing what you’re hearing inherently a crutch for poor monitoring?*

The 400hz high pass that you monitor through part time on every master would imply not. 

As someone with pretty good monitoring (80% of a Gerhard room and MUM 8s), I personally still find these kind of things very useful within a mixing context. 

I think you’re imagining a whackamole scenario of revolving bandpasses throughout the process and repeatedly throwing off the brain’s fr curve, when in reality it’s a once per mix check at the 85% mark that takes about 5 minutes total to see if anything that’s been overlooked jumps out when adjacent information isn’t distracting from it.

The way this helps me hone in on relationships between elements that I’ve been neglecting is pretty significant. I lean heavily “vocal > everything” when I mix, and nearly every time I do this bandpassing reframe I notice something I’d missed in the interplay between the rest of the elements and the whole project is upgraded as a result. 

I think it’s totally fair to warn against the pitfalls of such maneuvers in the same way that it’s fair to warn against abusing energy drinks, but when it’s just once a week before an intense workout, an energy drink is actually a big win with little to no downside.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Right, one of the frustrating things about it is that it sounds like it is doing more than it shows.

If you hyper focus it in one area and then listen to the delta, that can be the best way to address the annoying resos. And not have it mess with stuff you want in the signal.

If there is just one or two dissonant harmonics on a vocal mic that you never want in the signal, a notch filter is way better.

If it is an overall poorly tracked or annoying vocal, 1 or 2 strategic instances of soothe can really sort it out most of the time.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Also have done quite a few live recordings (mostly ccm) depending on how it is edited/tracked, the drum bleed in to the vocals will be something to figure out. 
A few things I have had a lot of success with:

-Waves “Clarity” run at a light setting can be surprisingly helpful (you can automate the depth too)
-izotope music rebalance can help with this too, but use it super sparingly and on a new playlist. 
-RX can clean up a multitude of sins…both editing issues and annoying random audio issues.

As far as rate, it really just depends. The ccm stuff I have done is always just as much if not more work than studio stuff I get. Charge accordingly, I would do full rate if you can.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I imagine the signal of , for example , a close snare mic of being an array of frequencies / wavelengths and periods arriving at the mic diaphragm , all at different amplitudes  . That eqs and filters then adjust the amplitude and rotation of some of those frequencies ….at a point in time …

But that then the all pass allows us to manipulate the time relationship without affecting the amplitude of the composite  frequencies ….. so we can manipulate what the “order “ of arrival
Of those frequencies is at a point in time . Is that understanding  wildly off ? 
I believe this is what people have used transformers for also ? ( The way they react differently across e frequency spectrum  )

author: Alex Gamble
content:
Soothe is an interesting one. Much like how every plugin manufacturer has their version of classic pieces (1176, LA-2A, 1073, etc), now we're starting to see every plugin manufacturer have their version of someone else's plugin! I can't think of any other examples off the top of my head.

I agree with the previous posts, a resonance supressor is useful and a must-have in the toolkit, but extremely easy to overuse. Don't get too caught up in the marketing hype that these will solve all your mix problems. That said, sometimes it's just what the doctor ordered.

author: Alex Gamble

I've tried it but I feel like it sort of defeats the purpose of what the plugin is for. Aren't you essentially drawing attention to resonances in the side chain material by unmasking them?

author: bobby k

author: Chris Lyon
content:
From my experience, if you focus it on low mids rather than harsh unpleasant frequencies while sidechaining, it can make room for the body of vocals or important instruments to cut through.

A lot of the time, those resonances are the defining characteristics of each sound so side chaining even to harsh high-mid info can allow the character of a focus track to cut while limiting the stacking of those possibly harsh frequencies with other tracks. 

Experiment with the sidechain in mid/side unlinked and you can get more aggressive with sidechaining the lead vocal to the instrumental. In a dense pop mix, it can be a lifesaver.

author: James Cronier
content:
I’ve been using the SSL native E-channel as a go to mixing insert on most every channel for the whole year. I turn off the VCA distortion by default (the extra THD is not welcome here). 

As a mixer, I find the stereo pan really useful in pro tools, the input/output gains handy, and the EQ and dynamics to be really versatile and consistent. I don’t have to think about building a chain, 90% of the time all the tools I need are there. Also, the EQ maps perfectly to the avid artist mix  encoders so I don’t need to look at the screen to EQ.

I’m a little skeptical that these other plug-ins would sound so much better as to really change things for me, but this discussion does have me thinking.

author: James Cronier
content:
If you’re on pro tools, an avid artist mix is $200-300 and will let you do plenty of EQ-ing and other processing with the screen off. *IF*  you take some time to learn what plugs map to it well. 

Even just pushing the faders and pans with no display is amazing. 

I don’t do it all the time, but sometimes if I’m stuck on a song, I will turn the TV off and use the memory locations, FF/REW and spacebar for transport. Faders, sends, pan, mutes, solos, and EQ all happen on the artist mix. I go this route every third mix or so these days, a majority of the time I don’t and I just write some automation on the artist mix.

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.

author: N
content:
I appreciate your insight and do believe it’s worth considering on my end.

Due to being self taught I’m sometimes unsure about what is and isn’t ok. Ofc there are no rules but it’s good to know approximate boundaries people follow a majority of the time IE. not being overly concerned with inaudible artifacts.

Not worrying about these artifacts that can only be heard with low pass is a relieving thought 

Appreciate your time in responding
